dialogues.speaker: -EARLY APRIL, 1841-
dialogues.text: We are close on a PAIR OF BLACK HANDS as they open A FINELY WRAPPED PACKET OF VIOLIN STRINGS. WE CUT TO the hands stringing a VIOLIN. It's not a high end piece, but it is quite nice. WE CUT TO a wide shot of the study. Sitting in a chair with violin in hand is SOLOMON NORTHUP; a man in his late twenties. Everything about Solomon, his mien and manner, is distinguished. But he, too, seems a hardy individual. Someone who has known manual labor in his time. Solomon begins to lightly play his violin, as if testing the strings, their tuning. Satisfied, Solomon begins to play vigorously. As he does, we make a HARD CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We come in on a lively affair. A dinner party is being thrown within the confines of a fairly stately house. In attendance are EIGHT COUPLES. All are WHITE and all are FAIRLY YOUNG, in their early twenties. The men and women are dressed in very fine attire. We should get the sense that for the most part they are people of means. The furniture has been set aside in the living room. At the moment the couples are engaged in the dancing of a REEL. The music they are dancing to is being played by Solomon, having cut directly from the tune he was previously playing. He plays with a light determination, and in no way seems possessed with empty servitude. Solomon concludes the reel, and the dancers break into enthusiastic applause, which is followed by personal thanks and congratulations from all. It should be clear that despite their respective races there is much admiration and appreciation for Solomon's abilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a Saturday morning. Clad in her finest attire is ANNE; Solomon's wife, a few years younger than he. We see also the Northup children: MARGARET who is eight, and ALONZO who is five. They are handsome, and well groomed kids. Anne straightens up the children. She finishes,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: she rises up and stands behind them, almost as if preparing to pose for a portrait. They all wait a moment, then Solomon enters the foyer. He stands and looks admiringly at his family. ADMIRINGLY stressed. It isn't that he doesn't have love for them, he does as well. But in the moment, he truly admires his greatest accomplishment: a family that is healthy and well and provided for. He goes to his children, and hands each a coin, then goes to Anne. Gives her a kiss on the cheek. The children giggle at the sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon and his family are out walking along the streets and groves of Saratoga. The streets are well populated this morning with many people out strolling. Most are WHITE, but there are BLACKS as well. They are FREED BLACKS who mingle fairly easily - though not always completely - with the whites. We see, too, a few BLACK SLAVES who travel with their WHITE MASTERS. These pairings are largely from the south and - despite the fact the blacks are slaves - they are not physically downtrodden, not field hands. They are well dressed and "leading apparently an easy life" - comparatively speaking - as they trail their masters. As they walk, Solomon and his family arrive to an intersection well-worn and muddied from horse and cart traffic. Solomon and his children easily jump across the muck. Anne stands at the lip of the puddle, calls for Solomon to help her across.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon... Solomon, turning back to his wife with a broad smile waving her forward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Anne. Jump. The children, now smiling as well, egg their mother on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jump. You can make it. I've done it. You can make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not ruin my dress. Catch me! Solomon moves close, holds out his arms. Yet, there's still just a bit of mischievousness in his eyes. Anne gives her husband a lightly stern look to which Solomon replies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will catch you, Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will. Again, lightly stern:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will. And with that Anne takes the leap. Solomon catches her, swings her around grandly and sets her down lightly to the delighted applause of the children. That done, Solomon takes Anne's hand and leads her on. As Solomon and his family make their way, among the slaves on the street, we see one in particular; JASPER. As he trails his MASTER he can't help but note Solomon and his family as they enter A STORE. His intrigue of this most handsome and harmonious group should be obvious. With his Master occupied, Jasper moves slyly toward the STORE. Frozen on the spot, Jasper looks on admiringly. Suddenly a voice barks out-

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Jasper! Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are inside the store of MR. CEPHAS PARKER; a white man and a supplier of general goods. Solomon greets him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Parker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Northup. Mrs. Northup. With money in hand the Northup children move quickly about the store looking for items to purchase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne looks over some silks and fabrics. Parker suggests

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new cravat, Solomon? Pure silk by way of the French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in need of a fresh carry all for the Mrs's travels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year's passed? Off to Sandy Hill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. Using a long pole, Mr. Parker fetches down a CARRY ALL from an upper shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something to suit your style, but sturdy enough for the forty miles round trip. Handing the Bag to Anne, she is immediately taken by it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At what price?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will take it. Children, come see what your father has just purchased for me. As the children run over - chattering excitedly about the new gift - they RUN PAST JASPER who has quietly entered the store. At the checkout counter sits a portrait of WILLIAM HENRY HARRISON, the edges draped in black crepe. Before the book sits a LEDGER. Mr. Parker asks of Solomon:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you would sign our condolence book. My hope is to find a way to forward it to the Widow Harrison. Sad days for the nation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, certainly. Poor Mrs. Harris and her children. I hope brighter times ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jasper looks scared, timid. It's as though he'd like to engage, but is unsure of as to how. Noting Jasper, Parker

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment, sir, and you will be assisted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we could discuss the price...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Mrs. Northup. A customer waits. Welcome, sir. To Jasper, with good nature:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shop well, but mind your wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignore the gentleman's nonsense. Now, may I interest you in a new cravat? Pure silk by way of the-- Before Parker can finish, the door opens. It's Jasper's Master, FITZGERALD. He's stern, clearly displeased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jasper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My regrets for the intrusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No intrusion. Fitzgerald looks to Solomon. It is a cold glare as though he wasn't speaking to, and has no interest in a response from a black man. Looking back to Parker:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne, busy in the kitchen, puts the final touches to the meal, which is just about to begin. Solomon, in the meanwhile, sits at the head of the table reading from a NEWSPAPER. He reads to his children solemn news of the funeral arrangements for the recently deceased President Harrison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Thus has passed away from earth our late President." Solomon starts from the top of the article.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "During the morning, from sunrise, the heavy bells had been pealing forth their slow and solemn toll while the minute guns announced that soon the grave would receive its trust. Our city as well as our entire nation has been called to weep over the fall of a great and good man. One who was by the wishes of a large majority of our

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: people raised to fill the highest place of trust within their gift. William Henry Harrison." A long moment of quiet, the family continuing to eat. Then, from Margaret:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you read it again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not just now, darling. Anne enters the dining room and places a large chicken at the center of the table. As she takes a seat, all heads are bowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For food that stays our hunger, For rest that brings us ease, For homes where memories linger, We give our thanks for these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, that was wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Papa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alonzo, do you have something to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I helped Momma make this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and you were such a good help. Especially making the gravy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa, I would very much like to learn how to play the violin. Could you teach me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but I asked Papa first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both of you, calm down. We will have our first lesson after this wonderful dinner. And on that note, let's start eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family all tuck in to their meal. The scene is one of warmth and happiness. 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon and Anne have fun and difficulty putting the unruly children to bed. They are tucked in, and each given a kiss good night. As Margaret lays down to sleep, Anne blows out the candle darkening the room. Silhouetted in the doorway, Solomon takes Anne in his arms, holds her tightly as they both luxuriate in the simple, beautiful gift that is their children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now alone together, we see Anne and Solomon wrapped in each other's arms. Beyond being physically close, emotionally close, they are just so very comfortable with one another. They are the very representation of a couple who are made for each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other for a prolonged time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three weeks. Two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the custom. I wonder what  you'll do without me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't stay idle.  SOLOMON's eyes lower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, it's good money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only I didn't have to share  your cooking with other people.  ANNE holds his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't.  They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are just outside the Northup house. A CARRIAGE waits with a DRIVER. Anne and the children are dressed for travel - Anne sporting HER NEW CARRY ALL. The Driver loads bags into the carriage. For her parting gift, Anne gives her husband a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travel safely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay safely. Anne and the children loaded up, the Driver chides the horse and the carriage heads off. Solomon waves a hearty good bye to his wife and children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon is now out for a stroll. He passes two men - two in particular - who stand outside conversing with MR. MOON himself: MERRILL BROWN and ABRAM HAMILTON. Brown is about 40, with a countenance indicating shrewdness and intelligence. Hamilton is closer to 25, a man of fair complexion and light eyes. Both are finely, if perhaps a bit garishly, dressed. Hamilton, as Solomon describes him, slightly effeminate. Moon, spotting Solomon:

dialogues.speaker: MR. MOON
dialogues.text: Call the Devil's name... There he is now. Mr. Northup...! I have two gentlemen who should make your acquaintance. Messrs. Brown and Hamilton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MOON
dialogues.text: Mr. Northup, these two gentlemen were inquiring about distinguished individuals, and I was just this very moment telling them that Solomon Northup is an expert player on the violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Moon is being overly gracious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking into consideration his graciousness and your modesty, may we trouble you for a moment of your time to converse, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We make a jump to a green space. Solomon, Brown and Hamilton are sitting at a bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A circus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is our usual employee. The company currently in the city of Washington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Circus too constricting a word to describe the talented and merry band with which we travel. It is a spectacle unlike most have ever witnessed. Creatures from the darkest Africa as yet unseen by civilized man. Acrobats from the Orient able to contort themselves in the most confounding manners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I myself in aide of Mr. Brown; an internationally renowned practitioner in the art of prestidigitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are on our way thither to rejoin the company having left for a short time to make a small profit from our own exhibitions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reason for our inquiry with Mr. Moon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. We had just a devil of a time in procuring music for our

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: entertainments. Men of true talent seemingly in short supply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we could persuade you to accompany us as far as New York... We would give you one dollar for each day's service and three dollars for every night played at our performances. In addition we would provide sufficient pay for the expenses of your return from New York here to Saratoga.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand this is all very sudden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consider it an opportunity to see

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's intriguing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there is any way in which you would give consideration to the offer... Solomon gives the whole deal one last consideration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The payment offered is enticement enough, as is my desire to visit the metropolis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are delighted, sir. So delighted. Though we would add that our travel plans--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We would like to depart with haste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As luck would have it, my wife and children are traveling. I will write her of our plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent! I would beg you collect yourself, then we may proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in his house, we see Solomon packing: putting some clothes in a travel case, and collecting his violin as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon sits down to write a letter; pen poised over paper with already a few lines written. But Solomon thinks better of it. WITH LITTLE THOUGHT HE TEARS THE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon enters the buggy, carpet bag in hand. Brown and Hamilton are waiting. They ride in a covered carriage led by a pair of "noble" horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No letter to post?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need. My return will coincide with my family's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're off then.

dialogues.speaker: -MID TO LATE APRIL, 1841-
dialogues.text: We find ourselves in a roadside pub. It serves the purpose of drinking and diversion, and little more. As Solomon plays his violin, Brown and Hamilton perform a decent, paired magic routine before a SPARSE AUDIENCE NOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the show, the pub now fairly empty, Solomon, Hamilton and Brown sit down to eat. Hamilton and Brown drink, but again Solomon abstains. Though Solomon remains cool, Hamilton and Brown put up a great show of being disappointed as Hamilton counts out what little money was collected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not an additional tip from a one of them. They expect to be entertained for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And not satisfied a bit despite giving them more than what they paid for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the national mood. There's too much grief to make room for frivolity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sincerest apologies, Solomon. You were promised opportunity, and you were given none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The opportunity is with the circus. A two man show poorly promoted, what were we to expect? But the circus bills itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have told you of the circus with which we are connected. Creatures from the darkest of Africa. Acrobats from the Orient who--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have described it, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. We need to return immediately to Washington. Solomon...I believe us familiar enough now, but forgive me if I am bold...would you consider making the trip with us? Solomon gives a bit of a laugh at the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entertaining at pubs and inns has it's place, but a man of your skills deserves better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear, hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And more importantly you would build your own name and following. The circus tends to attract those with the highest of reputations. An introduction here and there could amount to a lifetime of reward. Now would be the time. With your family away, an opportunity presents itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said as fellow artists as well as businessmen. Well worth the effort at least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You present a flattering representation. As my family will be traveling back shortly, perhaps I might commit only to one trial engagement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, very good, sir. Very good. I cannot recall being so excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a practical concern. If you are to continue on with us you should obtain your free papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here in New York, no. But we will be entering slave states and as a matter of precaution... It's to all our benefit we should not have to come to account for your well being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six shillings worth of effort could well save much trouble later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go to the Customs House in the morning, then travel on. Good business all around. 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The city is a swarm of people. At the moment the populace is displaying both sorrow and anticipation. Sorrow for the loss of the President. Many are dressed in black, and black crepe hangs nearly everywhere. Black armbands are frequently seen, and the occasional American Flag hung at half mast. As well, there are portraits of Harrison at varying locations. Having arrived in Washington, Solomon, Hamilton and Brown RIDE ONWARD IN THEIR CARRIAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A decent though crowded, boisterous and smoke-filled joint. Very lively. Solomon, Hamilton and Brown are among several parties drinking in the hotel's bar. As with seemingly everywhere in the city black crepes accessorize the background. Brown counts out $43.00 IN COIN on the tabletop. Solomon is astonished by the amount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-three dollars. All to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That...it's far more than my wages amount to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consider the remainder an advance from the circus. I cannot tell you...I honestly wish you had seen the expression of our director when I described your abilities. He was fairly overcome with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have invited him to sup with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. I did, but so many preparations before the company is to depart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow we shall prepare for our Washington debut. But tonight, our thoughts are with the great man

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: for whom this city prepared solemn memorial. He has passed from the praise of men to receive the plaudit of his heavenly father. A fine man has passed. Let us remember him with a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Hamilton and Brown hold up their tankards to drink. Solomon, a bit reluctantly, does the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another. Our departed President deserves all the salutation we can imbibe. Hamilton and Brown drink again, and Solomon does as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE MAKE A HARD CUT to Solomon outside of the Pub, in an alley, with Brown and Hamilton in silhouette, back-lit by the street lights. He is violently ill, hunched over and retching horribly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right Solomon. No shame in it. No shame at all. 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamilton and Brown help Solomon to lumber up the spiral staircase, passing the occasional bemused guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamilton is placing a spittoon near Solomon's bed, where a prone and reeling Solomon lays. Hamilton sits on the bed. As he strokes Solomon's sweaty face, Hamilton speaks sweetly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid that Brown and I haven't brought you much luck. But rough waters bring smooth sailing. Eventually they do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....So...so sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh. We won't hear it. We won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. A good night's sleep. And tomorrow...tomorrow you will feel as well and refreshed as though the earth were new again. Hamilton lingers a bit too long and a bit too close to Solomon for Brown's taste. With more than a bit of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamilton! Nothing more we can do for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such is the pity. Displaying an odd sort of disappointment, Hamilton slinks away from the bed. He crosses to, and BLOWS OUT A CANDLE. The room goes dark with a blackness more than night. Brown and Hamilton exit. Solomon lays in the dark and moans. His sounds becoming MORE AND MORE DISTRESSED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon stirs, then slowly awakes to his new circumstances. He finds himself in a nearly lightless room about twelve feet square with walls of solid masonry. There is a thick and well-locked door, a small window covered with iron bars and a shutter. The only furniture is a wood stool and an old fashioned, dirty box stove. As Solomon rises he sees that his HANDS are CUFFED - the chain running to a bolt in the ground - and his LEGS IN IRONS. At first Solomon is incredulous. But that emotion is replaced first by fury and then panic. He begins to pull on the chains, fight against them. He does so with increasing desperation. Solomon flails about, the sounds of the steel chains whipping and beating against the masonry. He grunts and screams without regard as the cuffs and irons bite into his flesh, but he cannot pull himself free. After several minutes of intense effort, Solomon tires, slows, then finally he collapses. And in this collapsed state he remains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon again awakens. He hears sounds beyond the door...footsteps. Eventually the door opens. Enter JAMES BURCH - who runs the slave pen - and EBENEZER RADBURN who works as a turnkey and overseer. As the door opens, this is the first light to seep into the otherwise near-black room. The shine is painful to Solomon's eyes. With no salutation whatsoever, Burch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, my boy, how yah feel now? Solomon rises up as best he can. With all the resolve he can put together he states what he considers to be fact:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Solomon Northup. I am a free man; a resident of Saratoga, New York. The residence also of my wife and children who are equally free. I have papers. You have no right whatsoever to detain me--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah not any--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I promise you - I promise - upon my liberation I will have satisfaction for this wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Resolve this. Produce your papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With confidence Solomon goes to the pocket of his trousers. He searches one, then the other, but they are empty. He feels quickly about himself, but clearly his papers have been lifted. Solomon's confidence shifts, but to resolve rather than fear. Papers or none, he will not be easily cowed. Still, Burch asserts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah no free man. And yah ain't from Saratoga. Yah from Georgia. A moment. Not a word spoken among the trio, but Solomon and Burch do some serious eye fucking, neither man yielding. Burch says again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah ain't a free man. Yah nuthin' but a Georgia runaway. Burch waits for Solomon to acquiesce. Solomon does not in any way. Both men exchange a long and daring stare. The two are clearly at an intellectual stand off. Burch, leans to Radburn, SAYS SOMETHING WHICH WE CANNOT DISTINGUISH. Radburn walks off-camera and returns with a pair of "instruments:" a PADDLE - the flattened portion, which is about the size in circumference of two open hands, and bored with a small auger in numerous places. He also carries a WHIP. A cat-o-nine tails; a large rope of many strands. The strands unraveled and a knot tied at the extremity of each. Burch says again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah a runaway nigger from Georgia. Solomon stands with a quiet stoicism. He will say nothing of the kind. As that is the case, Solomon is seized by both men. He is pulled over the bench, face downward, shirt still on his back. Radburn then STEPS ON HIS CHAINS, holding Solomon down in a bent position. With no preamble, Burch begins to beat Solomon about the back with the paddle. Burch strikes him wordlessly - no taunting, no sneering. Solomon screaming against each blow. His back immediately SWELLING WITH WELTS AND BRUISES. This beating continues on and on and on until quite literally Burch WEARS HIMSELF OUT with the effort. Dripping in sweat and panting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah still insist yah a free man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I...I insist... Burch regrets hearing this. Not from sympathy, but rather because he's nearly too tired to go back to beating Solomon. Yet, as if returning to work, Burch returns to pummeling Solomon. Burch punctuates the blows

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah a slave. Yah a Georgia slave! Burch continues to strike, and strike... This time until the paddle SNAPS IN HALF. Burch then GRABS THE WHIP. Hardly missing a stroke, he whips Solomon relentlessly, the flails cutting into Solomon's back. Again, Burch's arm tires before Solomon "breaks."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are yah slave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...No... Burch goes back to whipping and whipping, and whipping...

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON'S BACK IS NOW TORN OPEN WITH LACERATIONS AND
dialogues.text: OOZING WITH BLOOD. Finally Burch can whip no more. He pours sweat and sucks air, leaving himself just enough energy to take up his instruments and EXIT. Radburn lingers for a moment. He takes the irons off Solomon's legs. Opens the window some. As he makes these gestures, in a patronizing and confidential manner, one wrought with poor sincerity::

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seen a good many of the black kind just where yah're. Sick. Make me sick. Often times the situation was resolved, and I think; what was all the beatin' and abuse for? Things end as they should, and the violence was for naught. So why cause trouble when they ain't no cause for it? Be of a cooperative nature, and things don't need be particularly unpleasant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or, yah can carry on like yah been, and I fear yah won't live to see Sunday next. With that thought, Radburn exits. Solomon rests. But to rest seems like giving in to defeat. He begins pulling

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on his chains. But for all his struggling, the chain loosens none. Solomon calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me! Someone help me! If anyone at all hears him, they do not respond. Solomon continues his plaintive cry for assistance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beginning with a TIGHT SHOT on the shuttered, barred window of Burch's dungeon - Solomon's cries barely eking beyond the space - THE CAMERA PULLS BACK from the building, onto the city until clearly visible is the Nation's capital. It's icon's of freedom - the WHITE HOUSE, the CAPITOL BUILDING - fairly mocking Solomon's captivity. Simultaneously, barren at the early hour and cluttered with litter and the remains of previous day's procession, the city is a bleak and forboding sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IT IS DAY NOW. The door to the yard is thrown open. The harsh white light floods all over Solomon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a yard just beyond Burch's. The yard is hemmed in by a brick wall. In the yard are two men, and a boy. The oldest is CLEMENS RAY a man of about 25 years of age. He is well educated. JOHN WILLIAMS is about 20 years old. He is born and bred a slave, is lacking in education, and overwhelmed with fear of the situation. Finally there is a child about 10 years of age who answers to the name of Randall. Solomon, Clemens Ray, John and Randall ALL STAND NAKED. Though they try to cover their privates a bit, they are all aware of the uselessness of modesty. Radburn is present. He has before him A COUPLE OF BUCKETS OF COLD WATER. He throws water on the naked men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. Warsh up. The men, soaking in humility as well as water, begin to scrub with A SINGLE BAR OF HARSH SOAP passed among them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy, too. Get him clean. Solomon takes some soap and rubs it over Randall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrub now. Git 'em clean. Solomon scrubs harder. Randall - clearly cold and uncomfortable - appeals to Solomon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know when my Mama will come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush him up! Seeing Solomon has no answer for him, Randall begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama ..! Mama! Is she going to come? Doing all he can to spare the child from a certain

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet, please. Randall is becoming nearly inconsolable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saying anything to keep the boy quiet:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother will come, I swear she will, but you must be silent. Please. Be silent! On the seeming strength of Solomon's promise, Randall goes silent. Solomon looks to Radburn, who just throws water on the soapy men. 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radburn brings food in to Solomon; a shriveled piece of meat and some water. Just barely enough to sustain Solomon. Radburn also has a SHIRT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That old thing of yours is just rags and tatters. Need something proper to wear. Solomon doesn't move for the clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go'won. Put it on. With slow defiance, Solomon does as instructed. He removes what remains of his old shirt - the one he was wearing when first kidnapped - and puts on the one Radburn brought him. The shirt's ill-fitting and dirty. Despite that, Radburn says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. Tha's fine. Tha's fine. Got no gratitude?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Thank you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah keep bein' proper, yah'll see how things work out. Radburn starts to take the old shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! It was from my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rags and tatters. Rags and tatters. Taking the shirt, the "rags and tatters" as he calls them, Radburn exits, locking the door behind him. Solomon sits with the plate of food before him. He pushes the plate away rather than eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting together out in the yard are Clemens Ray, John and Solomon. Over time they have drawn trustworthy enough to speak with one another. At the moment Solomon is still trying to apply reason to the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randall wanders about in the background. As usual, he calls out for his "Mama." By now, however, his calls should feel like little more than background noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This can't stand. It is a crime. I believe now someone lay in wait for me. My drink was altered... We are free men. They have...they have no right to hold us. Solomon waits for a response from the others. They give none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need a sympathetic ear. If we have an opportunity to explain our

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who in your estimation is that sympathetic ear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men I journeyed with. I'm certain they're making inquires at this very moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would be just as certain they are counting the money paid for delivering you to this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were not kidnappers. They were artists. Fellow performers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that? You know for certain who they were?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fact is, Solomon can't say for certain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How I reckon the situation: whatever past we had...well, that's done now. The reality to come is us being transported southward. New Orleans if I were to venture. After we arrive, we'll be put to market. Beyond that... Well, once in a slave state I suppose there's only one outcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't say that to give you empty agitation, John...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For y'all. For y'all they ain't nothin' but that! But John was'n kidnapped. John bein' hold as debt, tha's all. Massa pay his debt, and John be redeemed--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, our masters will not come for us. John is nearly beside himself with panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now John's...John's sorry for y'all, but tha's how it be. Where y'all goin', yah goin' witout John. Massa take care of me. Massa take care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama! All three men turn and look. At the moment Randall doesn't call out emptily. At the door to the yard is Burch along with two women. One in her late twenties; ELIZA. She is "arrayed in silk, with rings upon her fingers, and golden ornaments suspended from her ears." Though a slave, Eliza was a mistress and has - to this point - lived well. This is reflected in her airs and her speech. The other is a little girl, light in skin color, of about seven or eight. This is EMILY, Randall's half sister. As she enters the yard Eliza squeals with high delight, then breaks into tears of both sorrow and joy. Clearly this is mother and child being reunited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Burch locks the yard door, Eliza clutches Randall. She is overcome with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My darling. My sweet, sweet baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later in the evening. Solomon now shares his space with Eliza and her children. As the children rest, Eliza drops into a lament as if pleading her case to Solomon who lends a sympathetic ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both slyly, and with a bit of aggrandizement:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I say I had my master's favor, you understand. Above even his own wife, I had it. Do you know that he built a house for me? Built it on the sole condition that I reside there with him. The added promise in time I would be emancipated. And for nine years he blessed me with every comfort and luxury in life. Displaying the finery she still wears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silks and jewels and even servants to wait upon us. Such was our life, and the life of this beautiful girl I bore for him. But Master Berry's daughter...she always looked at me with an unkind nature. She hated Emily no matter she and Emily were flesh of flesh. As Master Berry's health failed, she gained power in the household. Eventually, I was brought to the city on the false pretense of our free papers being executed. If I had known what waited; to be sent south? I swear I would not have come here alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliza turns to her children:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My poor, poor babies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the deep of night, all are sleeping. A KEY TURNS IN THE LOCK AND THE DOOR OPENS. Burch enters with Radburn beside him. Both carry LANTERNS with them. Hardly giving Solomon and Eliza a moment to rouse themselves,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Get yer blankets. Get up. Sensing that things will not end well:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, please don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear yer talk. Get in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't no need for all that. Putting hand to Randall's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jus takin' a li'l trip, tha's all. Don't want to frighten the chil'ren none over a li'l boat ride, do yah? Eliza gives a shake of her head to the negative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright then. Git yerselves up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We now have Solomon, Clemens, John, Eliza and the children. They are being cuffed together. As John is cuffed, he pulls back. Scared. He beings in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John's massa gunna pay his debt. John's massa gunna come for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not wanting to hear any of this talk, Burch strikes John several times in the head with a sap-like instrument. Weakened, but again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John's massa gunna-- Burch again strikes John until he's quiet. Curiously, Emily and Randall don't even flinch. Why would they? They are quite used to seeing this kind of violence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a word out of none a yah. Not a word. Burch and Radburn begin driving the shackled slaves from the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slaves are lead to a flat bed of the horse and carriage. They are made to lay down side-by-side. We stay with them as some sort of cloth is flung over them, obscuring and blacking out their view. At that moment, the screen is BLACKENED and we hear the sound of the cart moving in haste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Led by Burch, the group of slaves arrive to a dock. They are taken quickly up a gangplank and onto the steamboat ORLEANS as the CAPTAIN, CREW and a MULATTO WOMAN WATCH, but do not interfere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slaves are hustled down one at a time into a dark, dank hold among barrels and boxes of freight...and RATS. Burch comes around and "checks" the chains; makes sure they are all secure and locked. Satisfied, he heads up out of the hold. Radburn follows. Alone in the dark in the hold, John cries, as does Eliza. Solomon stares down Burch for as long as he can, as if wishing bad things. As if wanting to exact some measure of revenge. But the greater insult is that Burch and Radburn, engaged in conversation, take no notice of Solomon whatsoever. He is that insignificant to them. That fact, that reality, makes Solomon boil with a rage he cannot express in words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are now in the engine room of the steamboat, pistons  pumping, black oily cogs turning, the power and the  rhythm are both aggressive and hypnotic. A shovel comes  into view, feeding the furnace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The steamboat is en route between Washington and Norfolk. We tilt up from the violent water foam to the powering  paddles of the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down in the hold the slaves eat, pray. The MULATTO WOMAN moves among them, catching ELIZA's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheer up and don't be so cast down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clemens Ray and Solomon watch as the Mulatto Woman returns to top deck, the trapdoor locked firmly behind  her. Clemens Ray turns to Solomon with a deadpan stern  expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to survive, do and say  as little as possible. Tell no  one who you really are and tell no  one that you can read and write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clemens Ray turns away from Solomon, eyes lost into the  distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless you want to be a dead  nigger.  Solomon's face is one of a confused despair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a flat overhead view of the port of Norfolk.  Sardines are laid out to dry in rows, glittering in the  day's sun as if like silver pennies. A chain of slaves  enter the frame and are led one by one on to the docked  vessel.  MORE SLAVES - about 15 in all, of various genders and  ages - are brought on board. Chief among them is ROBERT  who fights viciously with his captors. "With all haste"  is shoved down into the hold.  Having taken their cargo as far as they care or need to,  Burch and Radburn depart. They do so without a word  spoken to Solomon or the others.  With this new and sizable batch of slaves on board, the  crew again CASTS OFF, and the Orleans makes its way  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon is back cleaning in the galley. As he cleans, he again watches Robert prep food. Robert's skill with a knife is not lost on Solomon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hold is packed tighter now.  Muzzle covering his face, Robert is shackled with his  hands tied behind his back. Solomon and Clemens Ray look  on.  A sailor descends the staircase and takes off Robert's  muzzle, shooting him a forbidding look. He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon, Clemens Ray and Robert, now in mid-conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say we fight.  Robert delivers this in a hushed voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crew is fairly small. If it  were well planned, I believe  they could be strong armed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three can't stand against a whole  crew. The rest here are niggers,  born and bred slaves. Niggers  ain't got the stomach for a fight,  not a damn one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know, we get where we  travelling we'll wish we'd died  trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Survival is not about certain  death, it is about keeping your  head down.  Solomon looks at Clemens Ray, agitated -- his voice now  raised above the previous whispers. Grits his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Days ago I was with my family, in  my home. Now you tell me all is  lost. "Tell no one who I really  am" if I want to survive. I don't  want to survive, I want to live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The steamboat paddles pound the water, filling the whole  frame. The vessel ploughs on south.  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slaves are asleep.  A Sailor descends the ladder approaching Eliza. He bends  down and attempts to wake the daughter by caressing her  face.  Solomon rouses, and looks across to witness the scene.  From his vantage point, we see Eliza stand to interrupt  the Sailor. The Sailor looks at Eliza, Eliza looks back  at him. Knowingly she leads him off into a corner of the  hold.  As she does so, Eliza passes Robert who jumps up to stand between Eliza and the Sailor. Stretching out a firm hand  to the sailor's shoulder, Robert's look says "No you  don't."  Clemens Ray is awake now, watching.  There is an odd moment of stillness between the Sailor  and Robert, an impasse.  We focus on the Sailor's face. Slowly, a greasy smile  erupts upon it. Back now to Robert's face, a look of  incomprehension.  Robert looks down. We follow his gaze to the knife that  has already been jabbed unseen between Robert's ribs.  The sailor withdraws the bloody blade.  A wide shot of the two men. Robert collapses to the  floor like a sack of potatoes.  Clemens Ray and Solomon react. Complete horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are back up on the deck of the ship. SOLOMON AND  CLEMENS RAY dump ROBERT's body over the side of the ship. Solomon watches as the body churns for a moment in the wake of the vessel... then sinks beneath the water.  Clemens Ray, with no sentimentality:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better off. Better than us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon's POV from the back of the steamship of Robert's  corpse slipping gracefully into the water.

dialogues.speaker: -MID MAY, 1841-
dialogues.text: A white male, fairly smart, with broad shoulders, stands

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clemens...! Clemens Ray! We are in the port of New Orleans, one of the busiest in the young nation. On the dock itself there is a bustle of activity as goods are loaded and unloaded from a various ships. It's a bit of controlled chaos as a VARIETY OF LANGUAGES are spoken and shouted while slaves are shuttled from the Orleans to a holding pen. Solomon, and all the slaves are overwhelmed by all that is happening around them. Two men - among many - are awaiting the arrival of the Orleans. They are JONUS RAY - Clemens Ray's master - and DAVIS who is the solicitor of Mr. Ray. They both look like they mean business. The moment the gangplank is laid, Ray yells for Clemens. Clemens, seeing his master, is nearly crazy with delight. He is, uncharacteristically beside himself. Ironically, his master now represents "freedom."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...My master... Master Ray, sir! Master Ray! Clemens pulls on his chain. As he does so, Several other slaves collapse in his effort to reach his master, like dominos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is in charge of this vessel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Mr. Jonus Ray. My solicitor has documentation verifying that the Negro named Clemens Ray is my property. As he reads PAPERS handed to him by Davis:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know nothing of--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are ordered by court to return that property immediately, or face charges of thievery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My duty is to transport goods. I am not responsible for their origin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remove these contraptions! To his mate:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free him! Biddee does as ordered. Once free, Clemens hugs and sobs over his master as would a lost and then found child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all well, now, Clemens. You will return home with me. (to the Captain) Consider this notice and warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, Davis and Clemens head away. Solomon seems both desperate and hopeful of some aid from Clemens and Ray. But there is none forthcoming. Ray and Clemens continue on - Clemens not so much as even looking back in Solomon's direction. Solomon stands and watches as they fade into the environs and are gone from sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hours later. The slaves sit off on one side of the dock, baking in the sun, awaiting their fate. THEOPHILUS FREEMAN - a tall, thin-faced man with light complexion and a little bent - moves along the deck calling out names from a list. The slaves STAND as they are called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oren. John. Lethe. Eliza. Randall. Emily. Platt... Platt! Solomon does not respond. Freeman looks around. He spots Solomon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, who shipped that nigger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burch. Freeman steps to Solomon. He gives him a looking over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand up. Solomon does as told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fit the description given. Why didn't you answer when called?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is not Platt. My name is-- Freeman strikes Solomon hard across the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name is Platt, and I will teach you your name so that you don't forget. (to the Captain) Shackle my niggers. Get them to my cart. 36.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CART
dialogues.text: Solomon is carted off along with the rest of "Burch's stock:" Eliza and her children, John and Solomon. As they move off from the port in a make-shift cart, it opens up to the frenzic, busy port. For the first time Solomon sees true and severe slavery. These are not visiting servants, such as Jasper was back in Saratoga. These are humans held in strict bondage - herded like cattle, chained together as if in a "chain gang." Slaves are evident not merely by the color of their skin. The residue and accessories of slavery are everywhere. Blacks almost universally display scars -

dialogues.speaker: THICK AND HEAVY DEAD TISSUE FROM LACERATIONS LEFT
dialogues.text: UNTREATED - brands, and are often missing limbs. Blacks are held in all types of shackles, from simple chains to elaborate bindings, to neck collars that are spiked. Some are muzzled or forced to wear bits. One slave is attacked by a dog and the slave owner. The dog pulls and tears at the slave's clothes. THESE IMAGES SHOULD BE A

dialogues.speaker: PRESENT, BUT NOT REALLY COMMENTED ON AS THEY ARE THE
dialogues.text: NORM. They should be a reminder that not only are people being oppressed, but that there is an entire system of oppression in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Burch's stock:" arrive at Freeman's slave pen. They are led in by Freeman and his house slave CAPE - a mulatto. The yard is enclosed by plank, standing upright, with ends sharpened instead of brick walls as with Burch's. Including Burch's group there are about 30 SLAVES in the pen. Solomon and the others look around and see nothing but downtrodden and despondent faces. Three men sit next to each other with muzzles and quietly stare back at this new batch of arrivals. One attempts to speak, but all that comes out is a muffled, unintelligible sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slaves are in various states of undress, men and women alike. They clean themselves, scrubbing with soap and water. Women wash their hair. Men shave, skin is oiled. Freeman walks among them, inspecting them as they primp themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slaves are given new clothes by Cape. The men are given hat, coat, shirt, pants and shoes. The women

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: frocks of calico and handkerchiefs to bind about their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an odd, ironic scene. The slaves are in a large and fairly ornate room within Freeman's house. CAPE PLAYS A PAINFUL TUNE ON A FIDDLE - background music - as Freeman tries to line up A SMALL GROUP OF THE SLAVES, he becomes less patient, jittery and nervous, knowing that his livelihood is at stake, he wants his slaves to make a good impression. Sometimes his patience gets the better of him, and his hands move freely in direction of the slaves. The business has the air of an etiquette class, though what Freeman is trying to do is coach the slaves into being more "sellable." He works with them in groups of five or so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tallest to smallest, understand? Are you taller than her? Then you'd go before her. Do it. Move. (to the group) Keep your heads up. A sense of direction; that's how you look smart. None of those saucer eyes. Rid yourself of that smile. Look like a goddamn grinnin' monkey. Put the least thought in your head. C'mon, now. Think of somethin'. Weary of Cape's playing, Solomon moves to Cape. He asks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you play a reel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah. I don't know no reel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I may...? Cape looks to Freeman:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sick of your caterwaulin'. Let him play, boy. Let's see what he can do. Cape reluctantly hands the fiddle over to Solomon. Solomon tunes it a bit, then begins to play. His fingers stiff at first, he takes a moment to warm up. But as he warms up he is, despite the circumstances, masterful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SLAVES ALL CLAP ALONG. SOME DANCE ALONG. All admire his work. Freeman chief among them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep on. Keep on. Solomon continues to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A damn sight better than you, Cape. A damn sight better. Cape looks bitter as Solomon plays on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We come in on an odd sort of sight; A JUMBLE OF ACTIVITY. CUSTOMERS have come to see Freeman's lot - the room all gussied up with flowers. Freeman moves among them, displaying them as a rancher would prize chattel. Freeman makes the slaves hold their heads up - "look smart" as he previously admonished them. They are made to walk briskly back and forth while customers feel their hands and arms and bodies, turn them about and ask what skills they possess. The Customers routinely make the slaves open their mouths and show their teeth. At times a MALE or FEMALE SLAVE are taken off to the side, stripped and inspected more minutely. One of them, John, is stripped and inspected. Cape, as he's done previously, plays his fiddle. A buyer - WILLIAM FORD; a man of middle age, and an attractive nature in his tone of voice - consults a list he's drawn up and asks of Freeman:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the price for the ones Platt and Eliza?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand for Platt; he is a nigger of talent. Seven hundred for Eliza. My fairest price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will accept a note?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As always, from you, Mr. Ford. Eliza is beside herself as it seems she is about to be separated from her family. She begs of Ford:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, sir... Please don't divide my family. Don't take me unless you take my children as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliza, quiet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will have the most faithful slave in me, sir. The most faithful slave that has ever lived, but I beg that you do not separate us. A BUYER interrupts the skirmish and approaches Freeman and delivers coolly, eyeing Randall-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your price for the child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see how fit the boy is. Like ripe fruit. He will grow into a fine beast. Randall is made to run, and jump by FREEMAN - exhibiting his activity and his condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six hundred, and that's fair and final.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done. He reaches into his waistcoat and retrieves his wallet, counting out six hundred dollars, placing them into the already extended hand of Freeman. Ford sees the distress and panic in Eliza; it visibly touches him. He now tries to buy EMILY to console her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much for the little girl? You have no need for her. One so young will bring you no profit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not sell the girl. There's heaps 'n piles of money to be made off her. She is a beauty. One of the regular bloods. None of your thick-lipped, bullet headed, cotton picking niggers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her child, man. For God's sake, are you not sentimental in the least?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sentimentality stretches the length of a coin. Do you want the lot, Mr. Ford, or do you pass on them all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will take the ones Platt and Eliza. Eliza grips her children tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not go without my children. You will not take them from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if to prove her wrong, Freeman puts a foot to Eliza and harshly kicks her away from Emily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, don't. No! Freeman, to Cape:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take her out of here. Cape DROPS HIS FIDDLE, begins to pull Eliza away toward the door of the room, but her screaming and pleading do not abate. IT IS CLEARLY UNSETTLING TO THE OTHER BUYERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep her quiet. Cape tries to muzzle her with his hand, but Eliza continues to scream for her children as Emily does for her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama... Mama!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play something! Get the fiddle and play. As ordered, Solomon takes up Cape's fiddle and begins to play lightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play! Solomon plays harder and more loudly. Still, it is barely enough to drown out Eliza's cries. Freeman gets the other slaves to clap along with Solomon's playing. Emily frees herself and runs back, crying but endeavoring to be strong-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't cry, Mama. I will be a good girl. Don't cry. I will keep my head up and I will look smart. I will always look smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make merry, all of you! Goddamn it, Cape! Keep her quiet or it's your damned hide I will take it out of! Cape pulls a rag, stuffs it in Eliza's mouth. Clamping both hands over her mouth, he hauls Eliza from the room by the head. IT IS AN UGLY, UGLY SCENE. 40A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driven in a horse drawn wagon by Ford are Solomon and Eliza. Eliza is sullen to say the least. With the loss of her two children she has dropped into a depression she will not be able to pull out of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive to the FORD PLANTATION. The main house of the plantation - the GREAT HOUSE as they are commonly called - is sizable. Two stories high with a piazza in front. In the rear are also a log kitchen, poultry house, corncribs and several slave cabins. The plantation is described as "a green spot in the wilderness." With the arrival of Master Ford there is a flurry of activity - the "excitement" of a new delivery. MR. CHAPIN, a white overseer, instructs a slave named SAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, call to the Mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mistress! Mistress, they arrivn'. MISTRESS FORD EXITS the house - along with her attending slave, RACHEL, who is a cook AS WELL AS SAM'S WIFE - and travels to her husband, kisses him, then laughingly

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FORD
dialogues.text: Did you bring all those niggers? Two of them? You got two?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make me something to eat, dear. The day has taken it from me.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FORD
dialogues.text: Let me get a look at them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chapin--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one's cryin'. Why is this one cryin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Separated from her children.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FORD
dialogues.text: Oh, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It couldn't be helped.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FORD
dialogues.text: Poor, poor woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chapin, tomorrow you will take these two up to the mill and start them workin'. For now make them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: adequate; fix them a meal, and have them rest themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. (to the slaves:) C'mon, now. C'mon. Don't dawdle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something to eat and some rest; your children will soon enough be forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Tibeats, stands before the slaves. Chapin hovers to  one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is John Tibeats, William  Ford's chief carpenter. You will  refer to me as Master.  Tibeats nods in Chapin's direction:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Chapin is the overseer on  this plantation. He is  responsible for all of Ford's  property. You too will refer to  him as Master.  This plantation covers many  hundreds of acres, and you will  traverse the Texas road between  the forest site and the sawmill in  double time. Any clever nigger on  that path that gets a little  lightfooted, I will remind him  that on one side men and  bloodhounds patrol the border and  on the other the bayou provides a  hard living, with alligators and  little to eat or drink that won't  kill you. No slave has escaped  here with his life. You're here  to work niggers, so let's  commence.  Tibeats begins to sing the song "Run Nigger, Run"  mockingly.  We cut to Solomon chopping logs and into the montage of  the slaves doing manual labor and arriving back to the  sawmill.  Lyrics for "Run Nigger, Run"

dialogues.speaker: A61A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Oh run nigger run well the pattyroller will get you  Run nigger run well you better get away  Run nigger run well the pattyroller will get you  Run nigger run well you better get away  Nigger run nigger flew  Nigger tore his shirt in two  Run run the pattyroller will get you  Run nigger run well you better get away  Nigger run, run so fast  Stoved his head in a hornets nest  Run nigger run well the pattyroller will get you  Run nigger run well you better get away  Nigger run through the field  Black slick coal and barley heel  Run nigger run the pattyroller will get you  Run nigger run well you better get away  Some folks say a nigger won't steal  I caught three in my corn field  One has a bushel? And one has a peck  One had a rope and it was hung around his neck  Run nigger run well the pattyroller will get you  Run nigger run well you better get away  Run nigger run well the pattyroller will get you  Run nigger run well you better get away  Oh nigger run and nigger flew  Why in the devil can't a white man chew  Run nigger run well the pattyroller will get you  Run nigger run well you better get away  Hey Mr. Pattyroller don't catch me  Catch that nigger behind that tree  Run nigger run well the pattyroller will get you?  Run nigger run well you better get away  Nigger run, run so fast  Stoved his head in a hornets nest  Run nigger run well the pattyroller will get you  Run nigger run well you better get away

dialogues.speaker: -END OF MAY THROUGH EARLY JUNE, 1841-
dialogues.text: We are in a wooded area. There is A GANG OF SLAVES chopping trees into timber. It is hard, laborious work made no more easy by the sweltering heat. Solomon is among them as well as Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slaves now load the timber onto a horse drawn wagon. Again, hard work done under the ever present sun. 42B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sam drives the wagon, the other slaves trudge along side by foot. We should get the sense the travel is long and tedious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a sizable work area on the edge of Indian Creek. There is much work being done, the slaves primarily employed in piling the timber and chopping it into lumber. As before, there is little doubt about the rigors of the job at hand. Working as a carpenter at the work area is JOHN TIBEATS. There are also various CUSTOMERS who move about placing orders.

dialogues.speaker: -EARLY TO MID JUNE, 1841-
dialogues.text: It's Sunday morning. All of Ford's slaves are dressed with their "finest" clothes - brightly colored and as free as possible of defect. The slaves are gathered on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the lawn just beyond the piazza. Mistress Ford is present as well. As the slaves listen, Ford reads to them Scripture. His tone is of a man trying to preach by way of compassion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "But as touching the resurrection of the dead, have ye not read that which was spoken unto you by God, saying, I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob. God is not the God of the dead, but of the living. And when the multitude heard this, they were astonished at his doctrine. Then one of them, which was a lawyer, asked him a question, tempting him, and saying, Master, which is the great commandment in the law? Jesus said unto him, Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind. This is the first and great commandment. And the second is like unto it, thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself. On these two commandments hang all the law and the prophets." Despite the lightness with which Ford speaks and the hope in his words, ELIZA SITS OFF TO THE SIDE - SELF-SECLUDED A BIT - WEEPING GENTLY. We should be able to see in Mistress Ford's eyes that Eliza's constant crying is unsettling.

dialogues.speaker: -MID JUNE, 1841-
dialogues.text: The slaves have broken for lunch. They snack on smoked meat and drink water from gourds. As they lunch Solomon reads from Sam's Bible to the other slaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he that is greatest among you, let him be as the younger; and he that is chief, as he that doth serve. For whether is greater, he that sitteth at meat, or he that serveth? Is not he that sitteth at meat? But I am among you as he that serveth. A white customer - WINSLOW - irate at the sight and sound of slaves reading Scripture, crosses over. He grabs the Bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From where did you thieve this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suh, the book is my property. The White Customer has no interest in Sam's answer. With flailing hands he STARTS BEATING ON SAM. Solomon tries to stop him. That only makes the situation worse, Solomon now the target of the man's ire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your hands from me! Ford comes running over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the commotion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your niggers are either brazen or rebellious. This one was readin' Scripture, and this one claims it to be his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is. A gift from his Mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You condone this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I encourage it. As a Christian I can do no less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can do no worse, Ford. A slave that reads is dangerous. Winslow moves off. He yells back at Ford:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the man who would allow a slave to read is unfit to own niggers! Handing the Bible back to Sam, very matter of factly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay him no mind. The word of God applies to all. In that you may take comfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is at the reigns of the wagon carrying the timber to Ford's WORK AREA. Slaves trudge alongside, same as it ever was. Only...it's not quite the same. Sam brings the wagon to a halt. He, and the slaves look up the road ahead of them. Standing in the middle of the road is a group of CHICKASAWS INDIANS. They are in their "usual" dress of buckskin breeches and calico hunting shirts of fantastic colors, buttoned from belt to chin. They have with them DOGS and HORSES. They carry with them the carcass of a deer. The two groups stare at each other for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The groups of slaves and Chickasaws are now intermingled. They "break bread" - actually they work on the carcass of the deer which is now roasting over a large fire. As well the group share a smoke on a pipe. One of the Chickasaws is playing a tune on an "INDIAN FIDDLE." The Chickasaws perform a customary dance; trotting after each other, and giving utterance to a guttural, sing-song noise. The slaves enjoy the respite from work, Solomon particularly taken by the music...if not entirely enthralled by it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a bit, Solomon rights himself and heads from the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon arrives to some tall grass at the edge of the river. Lowering his trousers, SOLOMON SQUATS TO DEFECATE. As he does, he stares out toward the flowing waters of Indian Creek. After a few moments, as though a thought far greater than relieving himself has come to him, Solomon stands and replaces his pants. Oddly, Solomon stares out at the water as though he were a man possessed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just beyond the WORK AREA Solomon speaks with Ford as Tibeats listens. Solomon is drawing in the dirt, making rough diagrams for Ford as he explains himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The creek is plenty deep enough to sail, even with a boat full of load. The distance from the WORK AREA to the point on the latter bayou is several miles by water fewer than land. It occurs to me that the expense of the transportation would be materially

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Materially diminished?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we use the waterway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a scheme. Plenty of engineers have schemed similarly. The passes are too tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I reckon them at more than twelve feet at their most narrow. Wide enough for a tub to traverse. A team of niggers can clear it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you know what of transport and terra formin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I labored repairing the Champlain canal, on the section over which William Van Nortwick was superintendent. With my earnings I hired several efficient hands to assist me, and I entered into contracts for the transportation of large rafts of timber from Lake Champlain to Troy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll admit to being impressed even if you won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collect a gang, see what good you can do.

dialogues.speaker: -END OF JUNE, 1841-
dialogues.text: WE HAVE A SERIES OF SCENES in which we see Solomon and a TEAM OF BLACKS working on the creek: CHOPPING TREES ALONG THE BANKS, widening out the shore... It's all just a trial for now. The work is diligent, but it is basic to this point. Still, under Solomon's direction, the slaves go at it like they've got something to prove. And rightly they do. Solomon also works on a narrow raft of twelve cribs with which he will transport the timber. Once this is constructed, HE PERSONALLY "SAILS" THEM UP THE CREEK WITH A TEST LOAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford and a group of slaves wait along the river banks just beyond the WORK AREA. All are expectant in their manner. A long moment passes with no sign of Solomon. Then, from up river, we see Solomon's raft of lumber winding its way. SLAVES CHEER, and Ford literally applauds the effort. Tibeats looks pissed. He has just been shown up after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we come into the scene, Ford is presenting Solomon with a fiddle. Not as grand as the one he previously owned in New York, but a fine instrument none the less. It is a gift of thanks for his hard work. Solomon's gratitude is easily expressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My great thanks, Master Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My thanks to you, and it is the least of it. My hope is that it brings us both much joy over the years. Following the statement, Solomon's not sure how to react. He remains grateful, but the thought of "over the years" is just a reminder of the altered state in which he now finds himself.

dialogues.speaker: -END OF JULY, 1841-
dialogues.text: The slaves eat. All tired from a days work they conduct themselves in silence. All except for Eliza who, SLIPPING INTO PERMANENT DEPRESSION, as always weeps. The sound of her sobbing edging him up - particularly after Master Ford's "over the years" observation. Solomon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliza. Eliza, stop! Solomon goes to her, grabs Eliza. She does not stop. As if to force the misery from her, Solomon SHAKES ELIZA VIOLENTLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it! Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all I have to keeps my loss present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You let yourself be overcome by sorrow. You will drown in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you stopped crying for your children? You make no sounds, but will you ever let them go in your heart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...They are as my flesh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then who is distressed? Do I upset the Mistress and the Master? Do you care less for my loss than their well being?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Ford is a decent man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is a slaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the circumstances--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the circumstances he is a slaver! Christian only in his proclamations. Separated me from my precious babies for lack of a few dollars. But you truckle at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You luxuriate in his favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I survive. I will not fall into despair. Woeful and crushed; melancholy is the yolk I see most. I will offer up my talents to Master Ford. I will keep myself hearty until freedom is opportune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford is your opportunity. Do you think he does not know that you are more than you suggest? But he does nothing for you. Nothing. You are no better than prized livestock. Call for him. Call, tell him of your previous circumstances and see what it earns you...Solomon. Eliza uses Solomon's name quite pointedly as if to underscore his true self. Solomon get her meaning. Yet he says nothing. Again, pointedly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you've settled into your role as Platt, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My back is thick with scars from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: protesting my freedom. Do not

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I accuse you of nothing. I cannot accuse. I too have done so many, many dishonorable things to survive. And for all of them I have ended up here... No better than if I had stood up for myself. Father, Lord and Savior forgive me... Forgive me. Oh, Solomon, let me weep for my children.

dialogues.speaker: FORD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: At the same time came the disciples unto Jesus, saying, Who is the greatest in the kingdom of heaven?

dialogues.speaker: -AUGUST, 1841-
dialogues.text: It's Sunday. The slaves are again gathered in the rose garden near the front of the house to hear the word of the Lord as read by Master Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Jesus called a little child unto him, and set him in the midst of them, And said, Verily I say unto you, Except ye be converted, and become as little children, ye shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven. The phrase seems to trigger Eliza's tears. She begins to sob uncontrollably. Mrs. Ford turns to Rachel in a hushed whisper-

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FORD
dialogues.text: I cannot have that kind of depression about. Solomon, pretending not to have heard, slowly turns to Eliza with worry. Ford continues to preach over Eliza's keening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But whoso shall offend one of these little ones which believe in me, it were better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck, and that he were drowned in the depth of the sea. Woe unto

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the world because of offences! For it must needs be that offences come; but woe to that man by whom the offence cometh!

dialogues.speaker: -JANUARY, 1842-
dialogues.text: Seasons have passed. It is winter now, and very grey out along the bayou. Ford and Tibeats - who we have seen working around the WORK AREA - stand with Solomon, Tibeats giving Solomon an inspection. Ford carries much lament.
