dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raise yer shirt. Solomon does as instructed. Tibeats looks at Solomon's back, at the scars from lashings he bears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troublesome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a good carpenter and quick- witted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am familiar with his cleverness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't find a nigger more humble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't found a nigger yet I cain't humble. Tibeats heads off. Solomon, highly curious over the preceding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, have I done something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not your concern, Platt. I say with much...shame I have compiled debts. I have long preached austerity, but find myself hypocritical in that regard. You'll be in the ownership of Mr. Tibeats. You are his now. Serve him as you'd serve me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your faithfulness will not be forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pride and want have been my sin. Loss of you is but one of my punishments.

dialogues.speaker: -END OF JANUARY, 1842-
dialogues.text: We see Solomon working as a carpenter, helping to erect a Weaving House that stands off to the side of the plantation's Great House. At the moment Solomon is nailing on siding. Tibeats arrives and is immediately dissatisfied with the work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make them boards flush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They is no such thing. Solomon runs his hands over the boards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As smooth to the touch as a yearling's coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Callin' me a liar, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a matter of perspective, sir. From where you stand you may see differently. But the hands are not mistaken. I ask only that you employ all your senses before rendering judgement. What's Tibeats to do when faced with fact? All he can do is spew invectives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a brute. You are a dog, and no better for followin' instruction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do as ordered, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you'll be up at daybreak. You will procure a keg of nails from Chapin and commence puttin' on clapboards. Tibeats wheels away. Solomon goes back to his work. After a few moments Solomon notices a bit of commotion in the drive of the great house. It involves an inconsolable Eliza who is being herded by Sam onto a cart DRIVEN BY A WHITE MAN. Mistress Ford and Rachel watch. Solomon can only watch as the last connection to his days as a free man is driven away to a location unknown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is day break. As ordered, Solomon is up and working. Chapin is rolling a keg of nails off a handcart for Solomon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Tibeats prefers a different size, I will endeavor to furnish them, but you may use those until further directed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the day gets on to mid-morning, the sun already baking in the sky, Tibeats makes his way over to Solomon. Even before arriving to Solomon his mien is one of belligerence; out of sorts and something less than sober.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I told yah ta commence ta puttin' on clapboards this morn'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, master. I am about it. I have begun on the other side of the house. Tibeats walks around to look over Solomon's work. He is picayune, as if purposefully looking for fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't I tell yah last night to get a keg of nails of Chapin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so I did; and Chapin said he would get another size for you, if you wanted them when he came back from the field. Tibeats walks to the keg and kicks it. Moving toward Solomon "with a great passion:"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn yah! I thought yah knowed somethin'! Solomon, perhaps inspired by his moment with Eliza, is in no mood for Tibeats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did as instructed. If there's something wrong, then its wrong with your instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah black bastard! Yah goddman black bastard! In an inconsolable rage, Tibeats runs off to the piazza to fetch a whip. Solomon looks around. He is alone other than Rachel and Mistress Ford who, shocked by that which she witnesses, runs out to the field to fetch Chapin. Solomon's instinct is to run, but he stands his ground as Tibeats marches back whip in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strip yer clothes! Solomon does no such thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strip!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not. With "concentrated vengeance," Tibeats springs for Solomon, seizing him by the throat with one hand and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: raising the whip with the other. Before he can strike the blow, however, Solomon catches Tibeats by the collar of his coat and pulls him in close. Reaching down, Solomon grabs Tibeats by the ankle and pushes him back with the other hand. Tibeats tumbles to the ground. A violent struggle takes place as Solomon puts a foot to Tibeats throat, and then in a frenzy of madness snatches the whip from Tibeats and begins to strike him with the handle again and again and again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yew will not live ta see another day, nigger! This is yer last, I swear it! Solomon ignores the threats, continues to beat Tibeats. Blow after blow falling fast and heavy on Tibeats's wriggling form. The stiff stock of the whip wraps around Tibeats's cringing body until Solomon's arm aches. Tibeats's cries of vengeance turn to yelps for help and then pleas for mercy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murder! It's murder! Lord, God, help me. God be merciful! And then suddenly, Tibeats shrieks-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa I'm sorry! Chapin comes RIDING IN FROM THE FIELD fast and hard. Solomon strikes Tibeats a blow or two more, then delivers a well-directed kick that sends Tibeats rolling over the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the matter? Tibeats struggles up and tries to present an air of dignity and control while he keeps a demonic eye on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Tibeats wants to whip me for using the nails you gave me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with the nails? With a mix of shame, anger and embarrassment, Tibeats says, as if being exposed-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're...they're too large.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am overseer here. I told Platt to use them, and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall furnish such nails as I please. Do you understand that, Mr. Tibeats? Tibeats answer is in the grinding of his teeth and the shaking of his fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ain't done by half. I will have flesh, and I will have all of it. Tibeats moves off toward, and then INTO THE HOUSE. Chapin follows. A long moment, Solomon stands alone. He looks around, not sure what to do; to stay or to flee. Anxiety mounts on his features. A moment more, and Tibeats EXITS the house. He saddles his horse and rides off to beat the devil. Or, worse, to fetch him. Chapin comes running back out of the house. He is visibly excited, and when he speaks he is quite earnest. Though he tries to project reasoned emotions he gives off an air of impending trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not stir. Do not attempt to leave the plantation on any account whatever. But if you run there is no protecting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you run, Platt, there is no protecting you. Rachel...! Chapin runs off to join Rachel. The two converse at a distance from Solomon, then they head off for the log kitchen. Solomon is now very much alone, and he waits for what is to come. AND WE WAIT WITH HIM. And we wait, and we continue to wait... Moment by moment, the dread of the unexpected mounts. Solomon's eyes begin to well. He has beaten a white man, and he knows that death awaits him.

dialogues.speaker: A SLIGHT PRAYER TO THE HEAVENS BEGINS TO FORM IN HIS
dialogues.text: THROAT, but he is too choked up to fully speak it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chapin has now returned to the piazza. He stands and watches, but does not move to Solomon. Solomon waits, and waits... WE HEAR THE SOUND OF DISTANT HOOFS which grow louder and louder in the manner of rolling thunder. It's Tibeats. He returns with two accomplices; RAMSAY and COOK. They carry with them large whips and a coil of rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tha's the one. Tha's him. Dismounting, they move with menace that is tinged with perverse pleasure and wordless malevolence. Solomon tries to fight back, but he is strong armed and tied by TIBEATS - his wrists, and then ankles bound in the same manner. In the meantime the other two have slipped a cord within Solomon's elbows, running it across his back and tying it firmly. Solomon is then dragged toward a peach tree. A lynching is in store. The naked horror of it intensely palpable. Solomon looks toward the piazza, but Chapin is now gone. Tears of fear flow down Solomon's cheeks. He is on the verge of panic; a man heading toward his own execution, he begins to struggle and fight. A rope goes around Solomon's neck, then is tossed over the branch of the tree. The trio begin to hoist Solomon. He gasps and gags as spittle flies from his mouth and the life is choked from him. With suddenness, Chapin comes from the house brandishing a pistol in each hand - Colt Paterson .36 caliber "Holster" pistols with 9" barrels. Chapin moves with determination toward the lynch mob. He is sharp and matter of fact. With the guns in hand, he really doesn't need to be much more demonstrative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen... Whoever moves that nigger another foot from where he stands is a dead man. I am overseer of this plantation seven years, and in the absence of William Ford, my duty is to protect his interests. Ford holds a mortgage on Platt of four hundred dollars. If you hang him, he loses his debt. Until that is canceled you have no claim to his life. Directing his attention to Ramsay and Cook:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As for you two, if you have any regard for your own safety...I say, begone! Ramsay and Cook don't need to be told twice. The pistols Chapin's gripping make the situation real clear. Without further word, they mount their horses and ride away. Tibeats remains, and his anger with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah got no cause. Platt is mine, and mine ta do with as I please. Yah touch my property, I will 'ave yah strung up as well. Tibeats mounts up and departs. There is a surreal moment as Chapin's not sure what to do about Solomon. He chooses to do nothing. Solomon is left dangling by the neck from the tree as Chapin calls to Sam in the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam! Get the mule. You must ride to Master Ford. Tell him to come here at once without a single moment's delay. Tell him they are trying to murder Platt. Hurry, boy. Bring him back if you must kill the mule to do so!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, suh! Sam mounts up and rides off, the mule demonstrating much speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOURS HAVE PASSED. The sun is now at its apex. The sight and smell of the red rose bush is more than vivid as Solomon remains tied and dangling exactly where he was left. The scene is both tranquil and horrific. Life on the plantation continues. The OTHER SLAVES work in the field. CHILDREN make their way playfully in the yard. It should all underscore the fact that a black, hanging even partially from a tree, is nothing unusual in this time and space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chapin walks back and forth with the pistols in his hands. Clearly he fears Tibeats returning with more and better assistance. And yet, he does nothing to alleviate Solomon's suffering. He heeds Tibeats words, and as though caught up in the middle of nothing more than a property dispute, he offers no further aid. Solomon's head lolls to one side. He looks toward the sun. The bright light flares off the leaves and branches of the tree from which Solomon hangs. The glare in Solomon's eyes offering him more pain than solace, but he cannot help but look upward. As he does, his eyes flutter between life and lifelessness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon continues to hang. By now he is drenched in sweat, and nearly delirious with dehydration. His lips dry and parched. He may not die from hanging, but he may very well expire before the day is over. Eventually Rachel comes over - timidly, and as though she were acting contrary to orders - and offers a drink of water from a tin cup, pouring it in Solomon's mouth for him. She then takes a small hand towel and dabs at the water which clings to his lips. Rachel then retreats, and leaves Solomon to hang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is just now arching for the horizon. Solomon remains, as though his torture will not end. Ford, trailed by Sam, finally comes riding up. He dismounts, and moves swiftly over to Solomon. With great heartache:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Platt... My poor Platt. Ford produces a blade and cuts Solomon loose. Solomon attempts to carry himself, but he cannot. He falls to the ground and passes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we come into the scene, Solomon lays on a blanket on the floor. Eventually, his eyes flutter, then open. He is in the foyer of the Ford house. As he gets his bearings, he looks around the interior. THE SPACE IS HANDSOME, AND WELL DECORATED. It is sharp contrast to the bleak surroundings, shacks and dungeons Solomon has largely been accustom to during his time of slavery. It will be the "first and last time such a sumptuous resting place was granted" during his twelve years of bondage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon doesn't have much chance to luxuriate in his surroundings. He hears a DOG BARKING just outside, and is unnerved. Has Tibeats returned to finish what he started? From a study, Master Ford appears with a gun in hand. He goes to the door, opens it and looks outside. He can see nothing. Satisfied, Ford crosses back over to Solomon. He is frank with Solomon regarding the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe Tibeats is skulkin' about the premises somewhere. He wants you dead, and he will attempt to have you so. It's no longer safe for you here. And I don't believe you will remain passive if Tibeats attacks. I have transferred my debt to Edwin Epps. He will take charge of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperate, urgent) Master Ford, you must know; I am not a slave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before I came to you I was a freeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am trying to save your life! And...I have a debt to be mindful of. That, now, is to Edwin Epps. He is a hard man. Prides himself on being a "nigger breaker." But truthfully I could find no others who would have you. You've made a reputation of yourself. Whatever your circumstances, you are an exceptional nigger, Platt. I fear no good will come of it.

dialogues.speaker: -END OF JANUARY, 1842-
dialogues.text: From the back porch, we come into the scene on EDWIN EPPS; a repulsive and coarse man. His language gives speedy and unequivocal evidence that he has never enjoyed the advantages of an education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps reads the Bible to his slaves, eight of them altogether. ABRAM; a tall, older slave of about sixty years. WILEY, who is forty eight. PHEBE, who is married to Wiley. BOB and HENRY who are Phebe's children, EDWARD and PATSEY. Patsey is young, just 23 years old...though in the era, 23 not as young as in the present day. She is the offspring of a "Guinea nigger," brought over to Cuba in a slave ship. She nearly brims with unconversant sexuality. MISTRESS EPPS, Epps's wife, is also present. She sits with, holds quite lovingly, some SLAVE CHILDREN. WITH THEM SHE IS VERY "MOTHERLY." We also see Epps's overseer TREACH. Treach constantly sports a LOADED PISTOL. Though Epps reads the word of the Lord, he lacks the tone of compassion with which Ford read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "And that servant which knew his Lord's will...WHICH KNEW HIS LORD'S WILL and prepared not himself...PREPARED NOT HIMSELF, neither did according to his will, shall be beaten with many stripes..." D'ye hear that? "Stripes." That nigger that don't take care, that don't obey his lord - that's his master - d'ye see? - that 'ere nigger shall be beaten with many stripes. Now, "many" signifies a great many. Forty, a hundred, a hundred and fifty lashes... That's Scripter!

dialogues.speaker: WE START THE SCENE WITH A PAIR OF BLACK HANDS
dialogues.text: picking cotton ferociously. As we move out, we identify PATSEY, a 23 year old striking black woman. The camera moves out again to a wider shot. This reveals several lines of slaves picking cotton, with Patsey way out in the lead.  We cut to another pair of black hands. This time, revealing SOLOMON, clumsy and unskilled hands, picking cotton. A lash bears down on him. It is August, "cotton picking" season. We are looking out over a cotton field in full bloom. It presents a visual purity, like an immaculate expanse of light, new-fallen snow. The cotton grows from five to seven feet high, each stalk having a great many branches

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shooting out in all directions and lapping each other above the water furrow. There is a slave to each side of the row. They have a sack around their necks that hangs to the ground, the mouth of the sack about breast high. Baskets are placed at the end of the furrows. Slaves dump their sacks of cotton in the baskets, then pick until their sacks are again filled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick that cotton. Move along now.

dialogues.speaker: RUSTLE OF LABOR, THE MALE CICADAS BUGS "TYMBALS" IN THE
dialogues.text: HEAT and a SPIRITUAL SUNG BY THE SLAVES. Despite the heat, there is no stopping for water. The slaves are "driven" by Edward, who is himself "driven" by Treach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon. Drive dem niggers. Edward moves among the slaves, applying the whip to them without regard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick dat cotton. Move along now, hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day's work is done. The slaves are now assembled in the gin house with their baskets of cotton which are being weighed by Treach. There is anxiety among the slave, the reason for which soon becomes apparent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred forty pounds for Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What yah got for James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred ninety five pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tha's real good, boy. Tha's real good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred eighty two pounds for Platt. Epps does not look happy. Treach says again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred eighty two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much can even an average nigger pick a day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This nigger ain't even average. Epps pulls Solomon aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hundred twelve pounds for Patsey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hundred twelve. Yah men folk got no shame lettin' Patsey out pick yah? The day ain't yet come she swung lower than five hundred pounds. Queen of the fields, she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred six pou--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't done, Treach. Ain't I owed a minute to luxuriate on the work Patsey done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damned Queen. Born and bred to the field. A nigger among niggers, and God give 'er to me. A lesson in the rewards of righteous livin'. All be observant ta that. All!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Treach. Now speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred thirty eight pounds for Phebe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit one forty five yesterday. Pull her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred six pounds for Wiley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much he pick yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred twenty nine pounds. Wiley is pulled from the line, huddled with Solomon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance, a flogging is going on. Solomon, Phebe, and Wiley are stripped, placed in a stockade and now being given a perfunctory whipping delivered by ANOTHER IDENTIFIED SLAVE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening, but the day is not yet done. Slaves attend their various evening chores; feeding livestock, doing laundry, cooking food. There is no respite from a slave's charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fire is kindled in the cabin. The slaves finally fix their own dinner of corn meal. Corn is ground in a small hand mill. The corn meal is mixed with a little water, placed in the fire and baked. When it is "done brown" the ashes are scraped off. Bacon is fried. As the slaves eat, Abram goes on in great length and with much emotion about General Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold my words: General Jackson will forever be immortalized. His bravery will be handed down to the last posterity. If ever there be a stain upon "raw militia," he done wiped away on the eight of January. I say da result a that day's battle is of 'mo importance to our grand nation than any occurrence 'fo or since. Great man. Great man in deed. We all need pray to Heavenly Father da General reign over us always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slaves are sleeping. There is a loud commotion. Epps enters, drunkenly, forcing the slaves awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up! Get up, we dance tonight! We will not waste the evenin' with yer laziness. Get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite the lateness of the hour, the slaves are up and now fully dressed. They take up position in the middle of the floor. They wait, poised like actors. Solomon strikes up a tune; Henry joins in with a pan flute and the slaves dance. They do so very wearily. The whole of it certainly more torture than pleasure. Epps, whip in hand:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's yah merriment? Move yer feet. As the slaves twirl about Epps keeps an attentive eye on Patsey. It should be quite clear that his primary motivation for holding dances is so that he may view Patsey twirl about the floor. This fact is not lost on Mistress Epps. A few moments of Epps's lust on display is all that the Mistress can bear. Jealousy mounting, she snatches up a CARAFE. With all her might she throws it at Patsey. It hits Patsey square in the face. TOO THICK TO SHATTER, IT LEAVES HER BLOODY AND WRITHING ON THE FLOOR. The dancing, the music stop. The slaves, however, react as though it is not the first time they've seen as much from the Mistress. Mistress Epps, screaming like a hellion:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sell her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, now. Wha's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will sell the negress!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talkin' foolish. Sell little Pats? She pick with more vigor than any other nigger! Choose another ta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No other. Sell her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will remove that black bitch from this property, 'er I'll take myself back to Cheneyville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to that hog's trough where I found you? Oh, the idleness of that yarn washes over me. Do not set yourself up against Patsey, my dear. That's a wager on which you will not profit. Calm yerself. And settle for my affection, 'cause my affection you got. Or, go. 'Cause I will rid myself of yah well before I do away with her! Mistress Epps stands irate, lost in fury and unable to even think of what to do. Eventually, optionless, she storms away. For a few beats there is only the sound of Patsey sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That damned woman! I won't have my mood spoiled. I will not. Dance! Epps sends the whip in Solomon's direction. Solomon responds by playing. Treach literally drags the prone Patsey from the floor, blood still spilling from her face. The slaves, as ordered, return to dancing.

dialogues.speaker: -AUGUST, 1843-
dialogues.text: The sun has only just risen above the horizon. FROM THE GREAT HOUSE THE HORN IS BLOWN signaling the start of another day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slaves are in the field picking cotton. They accompany their work with a SPIRITUAL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the slaves make their way in from the field, the Mistress calls to Solomon. SHE HAS A PIECE OF PAPER IN HAND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Platt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you find your way to Bartholomew's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can, ma'am. Handing Solomon a sheet of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a list of goods and sundries. You will take it to be filled and return immediately. Tell Bartholomew to add it to our debt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, Mistress. Solomon looks at the list. In a careless moment, Solomon reads quietly from it. He catches himself, but not before the Mistress notes his action. With high

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where yah from, Platt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who were yah Master?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master name of Freeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was he a learned man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He learn yah ta read?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A word here or there, but I have no understanding of the written text.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't trouble yer self with it. Same as the rest, Master bought yah to work. Tha's all. And any more'll earn yah a hun'red lashes. Having delivered her cool advice, Mistress heads back into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon walks along a well-worn path, shopping bag draped over one shoulder. We see his feet. As the walk slowly  gathers pace, Solomon suddenly turns left into dense  foliage. His tread is now a full blown sprint, trees  flash past as Solomon attacks his way through the woods.  The sound of branches cracking underneath. His feet,  heartbeat and breath almost deafening. He is desperate.  The violence of his advance abruptly stops, there is  silence. We see in a clearance a posse of patrollers,  preparing for a lynching of two young men. Solomon's  eyes meet theirs. The two men look back at Solomon with  a look of fear as one of the patrollers checks the noose  around their neck. Suddenly the bloodhounds start  barking and the patrollers turn in the direction of  Solomon. Solomon's whole body shakes with anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost tripping over

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the store, Sir, to  Bartholomew's. I was sent there  by Mistress Epps.  The patroller reaches out for Solomon's free pass around  his neck, yanking him forward. He looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get there and get there quick.  The patroller kicks Solomon hard, sending him on his way. Solomon walks on, looking one more time at the two young  men; again there is a moment of connection.  Solomon turns. The two men are hoisted up, kicking and  spitting, behind his shoulder.  Solomon finds himself back on the trail walking towards  Bartholomew's, his face now full of shock and

dialogues.speaker: A101 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: trepidation. He walks, fighting to calm himself down.  We move behind him as he continues his journey, a lonely  figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A general store in the township of Holmesville. Solomon stands at the counter as BARTHOLOMEW fills Mistress Epps's order. Among the items set before Solomon is a QUANTITY OF FOOLSCAP. The items are collected for Solomon and placed in a sack. Solomon giving little thought to them other than getting them back to the mistress. As he turns, he glimpses the regalia of slave restraints, of all different guises; chains, muzzles for sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon returns and delivers the items to the Mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, ma'am. No trouble.

dialogues.speaker: -JULY, 1844-
dialogues.text: Sitting on the Grand house's Piazza, Patsey is having tea with MISTRESS HARRIET SHAW, WHO IS A BLACK WOMAN. Though once a slave, she is now comparatively refined though not wholly so. The table where they sit is adorned with white linens, and they are attended by a HOUSE NIGGER. It makes for a tranquil surreal scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon is running flat out along the road. Running as though his life depended on getting to his destination in beyond a timely manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still running, slick with sweat, Solomon comes upon the SHAW HOUSE. As Solomon arrives:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Platt Epps, good Sunday morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Master Shaw. I've been sent by Master to retrieve Patsey. May I approach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may. Solomon makes his way over to the piazza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mistress Shaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nigger Platt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My apologies. Patsey, Master wishes you to return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sabbath day. I's free ta roam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Understood. But the Master sent me running to fetch you, and said no time should be wasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mistress, but I don't dare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you knowed Massa Epps's consternation ta be any lessened wit your timely return? Sit. Sit and drink the tea that offered.

dialogues.speaker: B105 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Solomon knows better, but he sits and the Mistress has tea poured for him.

dialogues.speaker: MISTRESS SHAW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What'n was Epps's concern?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'd rather not say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: L'il gossip on the Sabbath be fine. All things in moderation. Solomon is not sure what to say. He struggles to be as diplomatic as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you are aware, Master Epps can be a man of a hard countenance. There are times when it is impossible to account for his logic. You know he has ill feelings toward your husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Epps has somehow come to believe, as incorrectly as it may be, that Master Shaw is... That he is something of a lothario and an unprincipled man. A misguided belief born out of their mutual competition as planters, no doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt...if not born outta truth itself. The Mistress waves to Shaw. Shaw, unsuspecting of the conversation, waves back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm certain Patsey's well being is Master Epps's only concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin' Epps desire come outta concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant no disrespect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't heard you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant no disrespect to you, Mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha! You worry for me? Got no cause to worry for my sensibilities. I ain't felt the end of a lash in 'mo years than I cain recall. Ain't worked a field, neither. Where one time I served, now I got others servin' me. The cost to my current existence be Massa Shaw broadcasting his affections, 'n me enjoyin' his pantomime of fidelity. If that what keep me from the cotton pickin' niggers, that what it be. A small and reasonable price to be paid 'fo sure. Looking toward Patsey, speaking with great empathy:

dialogues.speaker: MISTRESS SHAW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I knowed what it like to be the object of Massa's predilections and peculiarities. And I knowed they can get expressed with kindness or wit violence. A lusty visit in the night, or a visitation from the whip. And wit my experience, if'n I can give comfort, then comfort I give. And you take comfort, Patsey; the Good Lord will manage Epps. In His own time the Good Lord will manage dem all. Yes, Lordy, there's a day comin' that will burn as an oven. It comin' as sure as the Lord is just. When His will be done...the curse on the Pharos is a poor example of all that wait 'fo the plantation class. Mistress Shaw turns her head to the side, catching a slave's attention. As she does so, the slave, a YOUNG WOMAN, commences to pour tea. As if to punctuate her thought, the Mistress takes a sip of her tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon and Patsey are returning from Shaw's. Waiting on the porch of the Great House, a drunk Epps beckons for Patsey, his lewd intentions obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pats...! Patsey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not look in his direction. Continue on. Epps does not care to be ignored. He lifts himself and moves toward the pair in a rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patsey...! Solomon moves between Epps and Patsey, cutting Epps off as Patsey continues on. Playing up his "ignorance" of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Found her, Master, and brought her back just as instructed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you jus now tell her? What'd you say to Pats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No words were spoken. None of consequence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lie! Damned liar! Saw you talkin' with 'er. Tell me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot speak of what did not occur. Epps grabs Solomon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll cut your black throat. Solomon pulls away from Epps, RIPPING HIS SHIRT IN THE PROCESS. Epps gives chase. Solomon begins to run around the large pig sty, easily keeping his distance. Epps, however is undeterred. He moves after Solomon as speedily as he can, which isn't very speedily at all. And quickly he tires. Epps is forced to bend over and suck air. Solomon maintains his distance, barely breathing hard. His breath returned to him, Epps starts up the chase again. Solomon runs on out of reach. Shortly, Epps again stops, gets his breath... And now in what should be quite comical, Epps again runs after Solomon. Again, Epps's vigor leaves him before he can even get close to the slave. Dropping down to the dirt, in a show of regret and piety:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Platt... Platt, liquor filled me. I admit that it did, and I done over reacted. It's the Lord's day. Ain't nothin' Christian in us carryin' on like this. Help me ta my feet, and let us both pray to the Lord for forgiveness. Epps extends a hand to Solomon. Cautiously, Solomon moves close, but not too close. As Solomon draws within striking distance, Epps lunges for him. He chases Solomon on until he is again out of breath and once more drops down. And again offering a treaty:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all done in, Platt. I have met my limitations, and I ain't equal to 'em. I concede to yah, but in the name of valor, help yer master to his feet. Solomon cautiously moves closer to help. Again he is attacked by Epps - this time by knife. Sort of. Epps is too drunk and tired to fully open the folding blade - and chased far around the field by Epps. ALL OF THE

dialogues.speaker: LIFE.
dialogues.text: Mistress Epps comes running from the house to the pair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Wha's the fuss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A misunderstanding is all. It began when I was sent to retrieve Patsey from where she'd taken sabbatical at Master Shaw's. Upon returning, Master Epps believed Patsey and me to be in conversation when we were not. I tried to explain, but it lead to all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? Ya cain't remain the Sabbath without her under your eye? Ya are a no-account bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold a moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A filthy, godless heathen. My bed is too holy for yah ta share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wha's...wha's he been tellin' yah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of yer misbegotten ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he would know what of anythin'? I ain't even spoken with him today. Platt, yah lyin' nigger, have I? Have I? Discretion being the better part and all, Solomon remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There; there's all the truth he got. Damned nigger. Damn yah. Epps pushes his way past the Mistress.

dialogues.speaker: -AUGUST, 1844-
dialogues.text: With the sun yet again high in the sky the slaves are working the field picking cotton. As before THEY SING A SPIRITUAL, the only thing that distracts them from the tedium at hand. But there is no distracting from the heat. We see Henry begin to falter before it... And eventually collapse right in the dirt. Though the other slaves take note, none move to help him. None dare. From Treach rather matter of factly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him water. Edward runs to fetch a gourd. He carries it to Henry,

dialogues.speaker: ANYTHING TO DRINK.
dialogues.text: Roused, Henry rights himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go'won. Git up. Unsteadily, Henry lifts himself and goes back to picking cotton. He joins in again with the spiritual, as if the song is all that can keep him going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slaves are asleep. Epps arrives, again without knocking, with his whip in hand. The slaves stir. Uncle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We dance tonight, massa? Epps remains quietly focused on Patsey. And it's clear from her apprehensive expression just what it is he's come looking for. This time there is no escaping it. As if to acknowledge the badness to come, Phebe lightly cries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On top of a wood pile, in the back of the smoke house - Epps shoves Patsey. He stops, stands as if gathering his manhood, then he's all over Patsey. He is rough and clumsy. It looks like something between an awkward rape and a virgin attempting his first sexual encounter. Patsey does not respond in any way other than to continually turn her head from Epps, but otherwise remain as still as possible. If there is such a thing, she is vicious with her passive aggressiveness. Epps's frustration mounts until - as the Mistress Shaw had cautioned - he crosses the line from passion to violence. He begins slapping Patsey to get a response from her. When that fails, he punches her which only leads to him taking up his whip and lashing Patsey MERCILESSLY. Still, she gives him nothing. Beaten, Patsey sits in the dirt among the cotton, Epps deep breathing above her. The desire for sex now having left him. Epps heads from the field. Patsey is left where she is.

dialogues.speaker: -NOVEMBER, 1844-
dialogues.text: As before, Solomon waits as Bartholomew fills Mistress Epps order. Among the items set before Solomon is another quantity of foolscap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon is making his way back to the Epps plantation. He carries with him a sack filled with the goods from the store. As he walks, SOLOMON LOOKS AROUND CASUALLY. When he is certain he is alone, he sets down the sack, opens it and appropriates A SINGLE SHEET OF THE PAPER which he folds and places in his pocket. That done, he cinches up the sack and continues on his way. 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon takes the slip of paper and hides it within his fiddle. Perhaps the safest place he can think of. He acts as though he's hiding away found gold. In reality it's more than that. For Solomon the paper is a first step toward freedom.

dialogues.speaker: -DECEMBER, 1844-
dialogues.text: It's another night of Epps's forced revelry. Coming in quick from the previous scene, we go from Solomon holding his fiddle, to playing it as the slaves are again made to dance. Mistress Epps brings out a tray of freshly baked pastries. She sets them down on a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment from the dancing. Come sample what I baked for y'all. The slaves, thankful for the rest as much as the food, file toward the tray reciting a chorus of "Thank you, Mistress." As Patsey moves toward the pastries:

dialogues.speaker: MISTRESS EPPS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There'll be none for you, Patsey. Patsey merely turns away. Her non responsiveness, however, serves only to incite the Mistress. Screaming:

dialogues.speaker: MISTRESS EPPS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yah see that? Did yah see the look of insolence she give me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen nothin' but her turn away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you blind or ignorant? It was hot, hateful scorn. It filled that black face. Yah tell me yah did'n see it, then yah choose not to look, or yah sayin' I lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever it was, it passed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that how yah are with the niggers? Let every ill thought fester inside 'em. Look at 'em.

dialogues.speaker: MISTRESS EPPS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They foul with it; foul with their hate. You let it be, it'll come back to us in the dark a night. Yah want that? Yah want them black animals to leave us gut like pigs in our own sleep? Epps isn't sure how to respond to the inchoate berating. It's an invitation for the Mistress to continue.

dialogues.speaker: MISTRESS EPPS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are manless. A damned eunuch if ever there was. And if yah won't stand for me, I'd pray you'd at least be a credit to yer own kind and beat every foul thought from 'em. Epps does nothing. The Mistress lets her anger loose. She moves quickly to Patsey, DRIVES HER NAILS INTO THE PATSEY'S FACE AND DRAWS THEM DOWN ACROSS HER FEATURES.

dialogues.speaker: FIVE DEEP AND BLOODY GASHES ARE LEFT IN PATSEY'S SKIN,
dialogues.text: the moment marked with appropriate screams. Patsey collapses on the floor, covering her bleeding face.

dialogues.speaker: MISTRESS EPPS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Beat it from 'em! Thoroughly cuckolded by the Mistress's actions, Epps takes his whip and pulls Patsey out of the house. His intentions are plain. All the slaves remain silent. The Mistress, however, displaying high satisfaction, entreats the others:

dialogues.speaker: MISTRESS EPPS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eat. Fill yourselves. ...And then we dance. The slaves eat, but without a hint of levity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We come up on the slaves who lay sleeping. All except for Patsey. She rises from her bedding, goes to a corner of the cabin and removes something from a secretive location. She then moves over to Platt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Platt... Platt, you awake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a request; an act of kindness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patsey displays what she took from hiding. It is a LADY'S FINGER RING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I secreted it from the Mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Return it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It yours, Platt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what cause?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I ask: end my life. Take my body to the margin of the swamp-- Solomon looks at Patsey as though she were insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me by the throat. Hold me low in the water until I's still 'n without life. Bury me in a lonely place of dyin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I will do no such thing. The...the gory detail with which

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought on it long and hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is melancholia, nothing more. How does such despair even come to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you not know? I got no comfort in this life. If I cain't buy mercy from yah, I'll beg it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are others. Beg them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm begging you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Why would you consign me to damnation with such an un-Godly request?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is God here! God is merciful, and He forgive merciful acts. Won't be no hell for you. Do it. Do what I ain't got the strength ta do myself. Solomon says nothing. Clearly he's not about to do the deed. With nothing else to do, knowing she is damned with every breath she draws, Patsey crawls back to her spot on the floor and lays herself down.

dialogues.speaker: -JULY, 1846-
dialogues.text: Hard times on the planation. Where previously the field in bloom was a carpet of white, it is now patchy and under grown. The slaves move through the field picking not cotton, but rather COTTON WORMS from the plants. The cotton worms have dined on the cotton and nearly destroyed the crop. We see the cotton worms in extreme close-up, moving among and destroying the cotton crop. Epps is beside himself as he looks out over his ruined field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a plague.

dialogues.speaker: TREACH, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Cotton worm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A plague! It's damn Biblical. Two season God done sent a plague to smite me. I am near ruination. Why, Treach? What I done that God hate me so? Do I not preach His word?

dialogues.speaker: TREACH, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: The whole Bayou sufferin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care nothin' fer the damn Bayou. I'm sufferin'. Epps looks among his slaves at work, his enmity growing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that Godless lot. They brought this on me. I bring 'em

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God's word, and heathens they are, they brung me God's scorn. Crazed, Epps runs into the field, taking himself from slave to slave delivering a whipping to all he can lay his hands on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn you! Damn you all! Damn you!

dialogues.speaker: -OCTOBER, 1846-
dialogues.text: Henry, Bob, Uncle Abram and Solomon sit in the back of a cart. SOLOMON HAS HIS FIDDLE WITH HIM. Epps has delivered the men to JUDGE TURNER, a distinguished man and extensive planter whose large estate is situated on Bayou Salle within a few miles of the gulf. Epps and Turner stand off to one side engaged in bargaining as Henry, Bob, Uncle Abram and Solomon wait and watch. One of the slaves whisper under their breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear cutting cane is twice as hard as picking cotton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But at least we'll be away from Master Epps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, you two have no sense. Epps returns to his slaves and gives a parting salutation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yer Judge Turner's for the season. More if need be, until my crop return. Yah'll bring no disrespect to me, and yah'll bring no biblical plagues to him. Be decent, ere mark my words, I will deliver an ungodly whippin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slaves are crammed into the shack - LITERALLY ON TOP OF EACH OTHER - as they try to sleep. Some lay, some sit up. Packed in like cattle, there is barely room to move let alone draw a deep, clean breath. There is a real risk of suffocating in the mass. Some cough and wheeze. A CHILD CRIES... Among them is Solomon who must believe at this point that his life has reached its very lowest point. The odds of survival are slight, let alone the chance of actually ever returning to his family. This clearly weighs on him as he struggles to find anything like comfortable space in the pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OVERSEER is explaining to the new slaves - SOLOMON AMONG THEM - how to cultivate cane. WITH A KNIFE IN HAND he demonstrates the process:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Draw the cane from the rick, cut the top and flags from the stalk, understand? Leave only that part which is sound and healthy. Cast off the rest...

dialogues.speaker: -NOVEMBER, 1846-
dialogues.text: ABOUT THIRTY SLAVES are working the field. They are divided into THREE GANGS. The first which draw the cane, the next lay the cane in the drill, the last then hoe the rows after. Solomon is among a gang that draws and cuts, and he moves with speed and skill. Certainly more so than he displayed picking cotton. Standing with his overseer, Judge Turner watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, the slaves have been herded into the shack and pressed together. As he tries to rest - sleep is nearly impossible - Solomon finds himself face to face with a woman, ANNA. She is awake. For a few beats she avoids eye contact with Solomon. She seems, like Solomon, to be unaccustomed to her surroundings and horribly frightened by them. Eventually her eyes meet Solomon's. She makes no sound, but great apprehension spills from her eyes. Whatever's next, whatever horror awaits, she can barely stand to face. Fear, proximity... They drive her hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to Solomon's. After a moment of seemingly reacquainting herself with genuine human contact, the woman TAKES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLOMON'S HAND AND PRESSES IT TO HER BREAST. Solomon tries to jerk his hand away, but ANNA HOLDS IT IN PLACE. Manipulating Solomon's hand, she begins to massage her breast. Solomon takes no real pleasure in the act - really, neither does Anna. THERE SHOULD BE A TRUE SENSE

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON.
dialogues.text: The need quickly compounds. Anna presses her lips to Solomon's. Eventually, SHE DIRECTS HIS HAND BENEATH HER DRESS AND BETWEEN HER LEGS. Solomon, with slightly more compassion than a guy making union wages, BEGINS TO MANIPULATE ANNA WITH HIS HAND. The act remains more perfunctory than passionate. We can see Anna moving toward climax and eventual release. But more - or substantially less - than joyous sex, it is really just a drug-like inoculation against reality. But the feeling quickly fades. All that remains, as with most chance encounters, is regret. And there is shame, too. This is put on display as Anna turns away from Solomon. As quickly as it began, it is as though the act had not happened at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon waits outside the house on the porch. A house servant - ZACHARY - approaches and admonishes Solomon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off the porch. Get off. Like a dog shooed away, Solomon steps down. Eventually Judge Turner exits the house and crosses to Solomon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Platt is it? Have you cultivated cane previously?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir, I have not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take to it quite naturally. Are you educated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Niggers are hired to work, not to read and write. Turner gives that a bit of consideration as he gives Solomon a wary looking over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You play the fiddle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard Yarney, a planter up the bayou, celebrates his anniversary in a three week's time. I will hold out your name to him. What you earn is yours to keep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind yourself, Platt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work over, the slaves congregate to eat. As Solomon eats, he takes note of the JUICE FROM SOME BERRIES ON HIS PLATE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon plays with a piece of cane, fashions it into some kind of writing tool, testing it in the mud. He then brushes over the dirt with his hand. 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Secreted away out near the edge of the bayou and sitting by a small fire, Solomon takes the slip of paper from his fiddle. It is yellowed, showing age, but still usable. Dipping the piece of cane - a quill - into the crushed berries, Solomon attempts to write a bit on the paper. The berry juice, too free-flowing, is unusable as ink. Solomon returns the paper to the fiddle. He has some scraps of food with him, which he snacks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a sharp object scratching onto a surface. The  tool moves on to form another mark. The sound is  repetitive and almost unbearable. As we move out, we see  the names Anne, Margaret, Alonzo. They are engraved onto  the violin, in the hidden area where Solomon would rest  his chin.  Solomon looks at it for a moment, moving his fingertips  across the engraving. His face full of loss.  Sadly, he lifts his instrument under his chin and leaning his head to the side as if to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A party has commenced at the noble home of one MR. YARNEY. A group of REVELERS have gathered and are on the dance floor, in fancy dress. Their faces are covered with a variation of decorative masks. The party is a feast of celebration. As entertainment, SOLOMON ACCOMPANIES A GROUP OF MUSICIANS, no more than three. And as he does so, they all play with jovial liveliness. Clearly a good time is being had by all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His playing done for the evening, Solomon is returning to Judge Turner's on foot. There is only the moonlight with which to light the way. As he walks, Solomon eats from a HEARTY CHUCK OF BREAD. Obviously part of his haul from the evening. Solomon again hears noises coming from the brush just up ahead of him. Solomon tears off some of the bread, kneels and holds it out before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mere. C'mon, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time, there is no dog. Instead, from the dark and the brush step TWO BLACK MEN. Solomon stands. He looks the men over - their clothes tatters and they themselves covered in dirt. It becomes quite clear they are not just slaves. A fact confirmed when they step menacingly toward Solomon, ONE WITH A SHIV IN HAND. At first it seems they want Solomon's food or money. Worse, THEY GO FOR HIS FIDDLE. Solomon has but a moment to brace himself before he is attacked, TAKING A CUT TO THE ARM. Solomon fights back, PICKING UP A PINE KNOT and striking his attacker over the head. That takes the fight out of him, and both men retreat back the way they came leaving Solomon be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside of the slave shacks Solomon's wound tended by Uncle Abram. As he works on it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Runaways I would expect. The Bayou full with 'em. They nothin' 'mo dangerous than a nigger in flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They acted out of desperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Act outta lunacy. Heads fulla stories 'bout life up north. Yah ever been north, Platt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And never should yah be. I hope that yah never bear witness the sorry condition of the northern black. Got neither no purpose, nor direction. They jus...they jus fall about the streets in search of sustenance of both body and spirit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know this to be so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two of my massas tolt me.

dialogues.speaker: -FEBRUARY/MARCH, 1847-
dialogues.text: Alone out on the edge of the Bayou, Solomon is playing a low air on his violin WHILE SNACKING ON SCRAPS OF BACON. As he plays, something appears in the distance. From the edge of the bayou, coming forth like an apparition arisen from the earth, is CELESTE. She is a young woman of about 19 years of age and far whiter than most blacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FEATURE THE SLIGHTEST TRACE OF AFRICAN BLOOD." Beyond that, she is pale and haggard, but still lovely. Dressed in a white gown, she emerges from the water. Draped on her dress, her period. A line in her skirt. It's very visible, but not shocking. A ribbon of red in her dress. Celeste moves to Solomon without fear or hesitation. As Solomon, startled, takes her in, Celeste says quite

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am hungry. Give me food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hungry. Solomon gives Celeste some of his food. Celeste, famished, devours it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Celeste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are your circumstances?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I belong ta Massa Carey, and 'ave been two days among da palmettoes. Celeste is sick and cain't work, and would rather die in the swamp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: than be whipped to death by the overseer. So I took myself away. Massa's dogs won't follow me. The patrollers 'ave tried to set dem on me. But dey a secret between dem and Celeste, and dey won't mind the devilish orders of the overseer. Celeste lifts her head from the food on which she gnaws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are some whose tracks the hounds will refuse to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me more food. I'm starvin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all my allowance for the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to me. Almost as if compelled, Solomon does as ordered. As she eats, Celeste aggrandizes herself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most slaves escape at night. The overseers are alert for such chicanes. But Celeste tricked dem 'n alight in the middle of the day wit the sun up at its highest. The place of my concealment now deep in the swamp, not half a mile from Massa's plantation, and a world apart. A world a tall trees whose long arms make fo' a canopy so dense dey keep away even the beams of the sun. It twilight always in Celeste's world, even in the brightest day. I will live there, and I will live freely. The overseers are a cowardly lot. Dey will not go where their dogs show fear and where it always be night. Others will join me in the twilight, and we ain't gunna be slaves no 'mo forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon isn't sure what to say. Before he can say

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celeste will come to you again in the night. You will have food for her. Celeste departs the way she came; as though she were a vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon stealthfully makes his way into the storage shed. Dried and smoked meats are hung, and milled corn is about. Taking out a handkerchief, Solomon begins to load it with food. Not too much. Not so much his thievery will be readily noticed, but he does avail himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon plays his violin, but plays it with an anxious nature as he waits. Then, as before, a figure appears in the distance. It is Celeste coming out of the night. She makes her way directly to Solomon. With no greeting, she says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am hungry. Solomon gives Celeste the handkerchief he's filled. She opens it, and begins to devour the food. As she eats:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was rude, and didn't even ask yo name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Platt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon. Solomon is my true and free name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was you free?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was. I am. Solomon exposes his wrist, displays his tattoo as he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remain free in my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giving a laugh as though it's the silliest thing she's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free heart means nothin if'n yo body gunna die a slave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? Celeste knows you ain't gunna run. Celeste knows it ain't your nature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a plan. I have a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A letter? How'll yah mail da letter? Who yah trust to post it? A nigger that can read and write is a nigger that'll hang. There is a pause. Solomon can't answer this question. It is the glaring hole in his plan. Having finished eating:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celeste will come again in de night. You will bring her 'mo food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I risk discovery to take more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will bring Celeste 'mo food. And with that Celeste again moves back into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon is picking at the bark off a WHITE MAPLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a tin cup, over a fire, Solomon boils the white maple bark in just a bit of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As others sleep, by the light of dying coals, Solomon uses the quill to test the boiled bark. The liquid holds as a form of ink. It is no?t ideal, but it is legible on the page. Armed with this, Solomon writes his letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon sits with Celeste. He relates his news to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have my letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah has your freedom then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that remains is to contrive measures by which the letter can safely be deposited in the post office. When Celeste speaks she is quite melancholy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have resolved to return to my Massa. Solomon gives an unnerved look. This is not good news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it more food you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live in fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None will come after you in the swamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't the patrollers I scared of... At all seasons the howling of wild animals can be heard at night along the border of the swamps. At first their calls were welcomin'. Dey too was free, 'n I thought dey greeted me like a sistah. Lately, dey cries have turned horrifyin'. They mean to kill Celeste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The solitude plays tricks. It's your impression, nothing more. If you go back to your master you could face the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My freedom been nothin' but a daydream. So was Celeste's thoughts of slaves conjoinin' in the bayou.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better the loneliness. You have been free most of the summer. Return now and your master will make example of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is lonely dwellin' waiting for others who won't never come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go north. Make your way by night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll only be worse if'n Celeste don't go back of her own will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't be caught. The dogs won't track you. You are...you are unique. Celeste...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got alternatives, Solomon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To return is to die!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celeste got no one to write a letter to. As if to punctuate her resolve, without a word more Celeste departs toward the swamp. Solomon starts on into the swamp after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celeste... Celeste! Solomon continues after Celeste, wading deeper into the dark night and murky waters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celeste, I will guide you north! Wait, and I will take you. Celeste is too nimble. She outpaces Solomon, continues on and disappears into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me take you! Let me go with you! Solomon runs on, then splashes to a stop. He stumbles around disoriented, calling into the blackness:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celeste... Nothing. No answer. Not a human one. There are sounds and echoes - some in the distance, some perhaps moving closer - which, moment by moment, become more and more frightening. Soon, Solomon realizes he is in quite literally over his head; the water first chest deep, then neck deep. With no way to orient himself, no means to guide him in the dark, Solomon's reserve begins to crumble. He thrashes in the water trying to find his way

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: back to shore. No longer trying to save Celeste, Solomon calls to her - desperately - for assistance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celeste! Come to me, Celeste! In that moment Solomon is quite certain he is nearly done; that he will not find land, nor aid and that this is his final moment. His panic should be that tangible. It is either force of will, or survival instinct...or maybe just pure luck that carries Solomon on until he reaches first muddy ground, then firm footing. Hauling himself onto the swamps edge, Solomon finally collapses in a drenched, worn heap. His life spared, but Celeste never to be seen again.

dialogues.speaker: -MAY/JUNE, 1847-
dialogues.text: We come up now outside of Master Epps's plantation. Epps stands in the drive. He's in surprisingly good spirits as Solomon, Uncle Abram, Henry and Bob trudge their way wearily toward Epps and his other slaves who are gathered. The cotton field is in full bloom, the crop fully returned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A joyous day. A joyous day. Dark times is behind us. Clean livin' 'n prayer done lifted the plague. Indicating to the cotton:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As thick 'n white as New England snow. 'N now my niggers is returned to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heard Judge Turner gave you favor. Oh, did you beguile him, Platt, with your slick nigger ways? Well, yah won't stand idle, boy. Not on my land. Much work to do. Days of old long since, eh? Joyous! Joyous indeed! Throughout Epps's welcome, Solomon's focus is on Patsey who is lined up with the other slaves. SHE IS NOW MORE HAGGARD THAN WHEN WE LAST SAW HER. Her face and arms display many new scars. It's clear that in the intervening years she has quite literally been a whipping boy for Epps and the Mistress. 94.

dialogues.speaker: -JULY, 1847-
dialogues.text: The slaves are out working on the field. White hands appear, picking cotton: ARMSBY. He is wholly unskilled at picking cotton, and he puts little effort into the job. As we meet him he seems a decent sort if a little short on self-motivation. In anachronistic terminology, he'd be called a "slacker." He joins in with the slaves, singing a spiritual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Epps said, it is days of long since. The slaves are back to having their cotton weighed in the Gin House

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wiley...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred sixty pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three hundred forty pounds for Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patsey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hundred twenty pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tha's a girl. Don't never let me down. Platt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred sixty pounds. Before Treach is even done announcing the weight, Epps has pulled Solomon aside to where Uncle Abram already awaits his fate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armsby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty four pounds. Epps speaks to Armsby sternly, but nothing of the manner in which he would address the slaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good days labor would average two hundred pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure in time y'll develope as a picker, but it takes effort, boy. Put some damn effort into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. To Treach, regarding Solomon and Abram:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take 'em out. Get to whippin'. No force is needed. The slaves understand the situation. They follow Treach out of the Gin house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We come in after the punishment has been dealt. Patsey tends to Uncle Abram's back as Armsby applies liniments to Solomon's. As he does, Armsby muses:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a tragedy. How does such come to pass? Working a field and picking cotton like a lowly hand. I'm of a damn sight better station. And my desires never lacked for a grandiose component, though I will admit they have at times been short on ingenuity. But only at times. I've worked as an overseer, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not "sir." Just Armsby. Not owed more than any other in the field. I worked plantations from Virginia, down into Alabama. I could manage easy a hundred slaves and have done so. But to toil in the field? Never thought that would come to pass. Never. But times are desperate. Where once I had said "no" to Epps and his merger offerings, I returned cap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in hand. ...Look at what I've become.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you arrive at such a place, if I may ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask. It's just conversation. From a pocket Armsby produces a flask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I became a little too dependant on the whisky, a little too undependable on the job. Before you say I'm just a sorry drunkard, let me state my case: As reliable employment as overseeing is, it's no easy chore on the spirit. I say no man of conscious can take the lash to another human day in, and day out without shredding at his own self. Takes him to a place where he either makes excuses within his mind to be unaffected... Or finds some way to trample his guilty sensations. Well, I trampled. Armsby takes a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with frequency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is your place of birth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maryland. Have you traveled there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I cannot say that I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine country. More seasonal than the bayou. A deal less humid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you leave it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To make my fortune, of course. I gave in to tales of wealth and prosperity that were the lore of the southern states: all that's needed being a patch of land and a few good growing seasons. Cotton,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: or tobacco. And then locating a proper bank in which to store your riches. But such profitable outcomes are reserved for the plantation masters. It's the lot of the rest of us to serve. So I settled on being an overseer, and failed as well at that. In the meantime my dreams gave way to reality. Now, I want nothing more than to earn a decent wage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And get myself home. Armsby takes another drink and leans back.

dialogues.speaker: -AUGUST, 1847-
dialogues.text: We again hear the sound of the HORN BLOWING signaling the start of the work day for the slave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the sun yet again high in the sky the slaves are working the field picking cotton. As before they sing a spiritual, the only thing that distracts them from the tedium at hand. But there is no distracting from the heat. We see Uncle Abram begin to falter and finally drop down to the ground. Treach calls to Edward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him water. Edward runs to fetch water which he carries to Abram and DUMPS ON HIM...BUT ABRAM DOES NOT RISE. DOES NOT MOVE. At this point, the sounds of the singing from the others tapers off as they realize Abram isn't getting up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are beyond the main of the plantation, the cotton field in the background. We are at the slaves' cemetery, a mixture of crude crosses and unsettled ground. Solomon, Bob and Henry, now much visually older than when we first saw them, are digging a grave in the dirt. The uncovered body of Abram lays near. Having dug down an appropriate distance, the three men take the body and, very unceremoniously, place it into the ground. Holding

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the shovel in his hands, and resting it by his feet, Bob tilts his head down and closes his eyes. The others do the same. Almost stutteringly, not really knowing what to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to say something about Uncle Abram. He was a good man and he always looked out for us since we were little. God Bless him. God love him. And God keep him. That done, they begin to cover it with dirt. It is all the more of a funeral that Abram will receive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A female voice appears out of the blackness and begins to sing solo, "Went down to the river Jordan." A response of "Oh Yeah" quickly follows. Again the singer continues, "where John baptized three." The same faces we have seen on Epps' plantation, but now filled with rapture, appear. It's as if the voices have created a new form of awakening and presence. It seems to transcend and translate in a strange way, joy. A joy which has un-yet been seen on screen. A joy which has been hidden, but a joy which is undoubtedly there. It's captivating, infectious. This should be a moving part of the film, which stirs the audience and, for a moment, relieves them of the seemingly chastising environment. The singer continues, "Well some say John was a Baptist, some say John was a Jew, but I say John was a preacher, because the Bible says so too, preach on Johnny." And with that, the rest of the congregation chant "I believe. Oh, I believe."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon goes to RETRIEVE THE SMALL PACKAGE FROM UNDER A ROCK AT THE BASE OF A TREE. Solomon returns the letter to hiding. He takes the money with him and cautiously moves from the area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. Solomon enters. Armsby is surprised to see him. So much so, he isn't sure what greeting to give. Solomon gives a blunt introduction. Re: the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The proceeds of my fiddling performances. A few picayunes, but all I have in the world. I promise them to you if you will do me the favor I require. But I beg you not to expose me if you cannot grant the request.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, your word, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On my honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a simple enough request. I ask only that you deposit a letter in the Marksville post office. And that you keep the action an inviolable secret forever. The details of the letter are of no consequence. Even at that, there would be an imposition of much pain and suffering were it known I was the author. A patron is what I require, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the letter now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It is not yet written. I will have it in a day. Two at most, my skill with composition as poor as it is. Armsby considers the request.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will do it. And will accept whatever payment is offered. Solomon hesitates. In the moment, he's not so sure he can wholly give himself over to trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To assist you, I put my own self at risk. I will do so, but fair compensation is all I ask. Solomon hands over the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Draw up your letter. We will meet again. In two days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In two days. ...Thank you. Solomon exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon and the slaves pick cotton. Armsby is conspicuously NOT laboring in the field. As Solomon works he is watched by Epps. Watched more than he normally is.
