For a moment it seems it might just be a matter of perspective; Solomon's unease over his actions. But soon Epps is joined by Armsby. The two men stand and talk, their looks locked toward Solomon. Whatever it is that is occurring between them continues for a long, long moment. But Epps makes no move toward Solomon. Solomon continues with his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slaves are at rest. Gripping his whip Epps enters, without so much as a knock at the door. For a moment there's curiosity; is he there for a dance, for Patsey...? Looking right to Solomon:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up. Solomon does. Epps heads back out into the dark. He says nothing, but his directive is clear: Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon comes out into the dark. Nearly hidden in the shadows is a bitter Epps. Despite the lack of light, Epps's malevolence is quite clear. His whip attached to his hip. As he speaks, he stokes himself with swigs from a FLASK. Epps puts his arm around Solomon, as if consoling a friend, and guides him into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, boy. I understand I've got a larned nigger that writes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: letters and tries to get white fellows to mail 'em. Solomon, hardly missing a beat, plays this off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Armsby tol' me today the devil was among my niggers. That I had one that needed close watchin' or he would run away. When I axed him why, he said you come over to him and waked him up in the middle of the night and wanted him to carry a letter to Marksville. What have yah got to say to that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I have to say, master, is all that need be said. There is no truth in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I write a letter without ink or paper? There is nobody I want to write to 'cause I hain't got no friends living as I know of. That Armsby is a lying drunken fellow. You know this, just as you know that I am constant in truth. Now, master, I can see what that Armsby is after, plain enough. Didn't he want you to hire him for an overseer? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. He wants to make you believe we're all going to run away and then he thinks you'll hire an overseer to watch us. He believes you are soft soap. He's given to such talk. I believe he's just made this story out of whole cloth, 'cause he wants to get a situation. It's all a lie, master, you may depend on't. It's all a lie. For a tense moment we are unsure which way Epps'll go. Increasingly it become apparent that, shallow minded and equally soused, Solomon has been able to fold Epps's thoughts. In a low curse that clearly states his ill intentions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revealed is a pocket knife, which all through the conversation, unknown to us the audience, was pushed up against Solomon's stomach. As Epps speaks, he closes it and taps it on Solomon's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm damned. I'll be god... Were he not free and white, Platt. Were he not free and white. Epps heads off. Solomon is left to exhale a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having found a lonely spot, Solomon has struck a SMALL FIRE. He has in his hand his letter. With no ceremony, he casts the letter upon the flames and watches it burn. And with it, at this time, seems all chance of him ever being free. He stands and looks at it as if forever, as ashes descend into the night sky. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: -MARCH, 1852-
dialogues.text: The slaves are now employed working on an extension to the Great House. The slaves work under the direction of MR. SAMUEL BASS, a between forty and fifty years old, of light complexion and light hair. He is cool and self- possessed, fond of argument, but always speaking with extreme deliberation as well as a Canadian accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the slaves continue to work, there is a conversation going on between Epps and Bass. Bass much skilled in the art of sophistry, while Epps's arguments are fueled mostly by emotion alone. Though at first Epps does little more than joke his way around the facts. Solomon, working still, can't help but overhear as Epps offers Bass a drink, which Bass waves away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it. You look unsettled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shame in taking respite from the heat; drink, shade. It's ungodly for travelers. Hearty, or otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: B155 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bass gives a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant no joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your humor is inadvertent. Sensing perhaps Bass's laughter might be at his expense, Epps presses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then share what's funny. Or what ills you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here to complete the work at hand. As requested, and as paid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something rubs you wrongly. Before I take further offense, I offer you the opportunity to speak on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ask plainly, I will tell you plainly. What I find amusing: You worry about my well being in the heat but, quite frankly, the condition of your laborers--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The condition of my..." What in the hell are you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is horrid. It's all wrong. All wrong, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ain't hired help. They're my slaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say that with pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say it as fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the conversation concerns what is factual and what is not; there's no justice nor righteousness in slavery. I wouldn't own a slave if I was rich as Croesus, which I am not, as is perfectly well understood. More particularly among my creditors. There's another humbug: the credit system. Humbug, sir. No credit, no debt. Credit leads a man into temptation. Cash down is the only thing that will deliver him from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: evil. But this question of slavery; what right have you to your niggers when you come down to the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What right? I bought 'em. I paid for 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you did. The law says you have the right to hold a nigger, but begging the law's pardon...it lies. Is everything right because the law allows it? Suppose they'd pass a law taking away your liberty and making you a slave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ain't a supposable case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because the law states that your liberties are undeniable? Because society deems it so? Laws change. Social systems crumble. Universal truths are constant. It is a fact, it is a plain fact that what is true and right is true and right for all. White and black alike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, whoa. Yah compare me to a nigger, Bass? Yah might as well ask what the difference is between a white man and a baboon. Now, I seen one of them critters in Orleans that knowed just as much as any nigger I got. Yah'd call them fellers citizens, I s'pose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look here; you can't laugh me down in that way. These niggers are human beings. If they are allowed to scale no higher than brute animals, you and men like you will have to answer for it. There's an

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fearful ill, resting on this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You betray yourself a foreigner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That will not go unpunished forever. There will be a reckoning yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like to hear yourself talk, Bass, better than any man I know of. Yah'd argue that black was white, or white black if anybody would contradict you. A fine supposition if yah lived among Yankees in New England. But yah don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You most assuredly do not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Sabbath. The slaves are left to themselves to do their own chores. At the moment the female slaves are washing their clothes in large cauldrons, slapping their clothes against washing boards and hanging them up to dry near to their living quarters behind the plantation. It is a sight of ritual. Missing from the field of labor is Patsey, for whom Epps hollers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patsey... Patsey! A drunk Epps asks of the slaves:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she? Where is Patsey? No one answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk, Damn you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know nothin' of her, Massa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell you don't! You know where she is! She run off, ain't she? She's escaped, and you miserable black dogs stand like

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the deef and dumb. Speak! Speak! Not a word spoken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My best cotton picking nigger! My best. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd give yah all up for her. Where she gone? The slaves say nothing. There is nothing for them to say. They don't know where she is. Eventually Epps drops into true sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gone... My Pats gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps sits on the piazza looking quite forlorn. He looks up only to see PATSEY RETURNING TO THE PLANTATION. Epps steps up to greet her, with anger rather than relief. As they hear his angry voice, the slaves step around from where they are hanging their laundry to dry. Treach is near as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run off. Run off, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You miserable wench! Where you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lies to your misdeeds!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sabbath day, Massa. I took me a walk to commune wit da Lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring the Lord into yer deceptions? Yah Godless... Shaw's. Comin' from Shaw's plantation weren't yah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah took yerself ta pleasure Shaw. Yah gave baser passion to that unblushin' libertine! Solomon tries to intervene:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now yah speak? Now that yah want to add to 'er lies yah find yer tongue. Epps goes to strike Solomon, but Patsey pulls his arm back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not strike him. I went to Massa Shaw's plantation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah admit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freely. And you know why. Patsey takes soap from the pocket of her dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got this from Mistress Shaw. Mistress Epps won't even grant me no soap ta clean with. Stink so much I make myself gag. Five hundred pounds 'a cotton day in, day out. More than any man here. And 'fo that I will be clean; that all I ax. Dis here what I went to Shaw's 'fo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord knows that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you blind wit yer own covetousness. I don't lie, Massa. If you kill me, I'll stick ta that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll learn you to go to Shaw's. Treach, go get some line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Treach runs quickly to the tool shed. In short order he returns with the rope in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strip her. Strike her bare 'n lash her to the post. Mistress Epps has now come from the Great House. She gazes on the scene with an air of heartless satisfaction. Now tied to the post, Epps stands behind Patsey with his whip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah done this to yerself, Pats! Epps hoists the whip to strike, holds it high...but no matter his rage, Epps cannot bring himself to deliver the blow. He looks to Mistress Epps who now stands gloating and spurring him on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it! Strike the life from her. Epps again hoists the whip. It trembles in his hand ahead of the act... But he does not have it in him to deliver such a beating. Turning to Solomon, thrusting the whip at him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat her. Solomon doesn't move. Epps shoves the whip into his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give her the whip. Give it all to her! Patsey, begging to Solomon:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather it you, Platt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strike her, or yah'll get the same!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon takes a step back. He unfurls the whip... He begins to whip Patsey. Lash after lash, Patsey squirms before it. Epps eyes fill with tears, he is nearly too distraught to watch. But the Mistress... She is not satisfied with Solomon's half-hearted effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pantomimes. There ain't barely a welt on her. That's what your niggers make of yah; a fool fer the takin'. Epps's grief is replaced by fury. EPPS GRABS THE PISTOL FROM TREACH'S HOLSTER and draws down on the slaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah will strike her. Yah will strike her until her flesh is rent and meat and blood flow equal, or I will kill every nigger in my sight! Solomon can't strike a blow, even if it means his life. But from the ground, from Patsey:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it, Platt. Don't stop until I am dead. What else can he do? Solomon begins to whip, to truly whip Patsey. Her back welts, then tears... Patsey screams in agony. Solomon strikes again and again... After a full thirty lashes Solomon looks to Epps, who is not satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until I say no more! I ain't said nothing! Solomon strikes another ten to fifteen times. By now, as promised, Patsey's back has been reduced to LITTLE MORE THAN TORN MEAT AND BLOOD. Finally, Solomon holds low the whip. He can and will do no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strike her! Strike her! Solomon will not. Epps takes up the whip and whips Patsey with "ten fold" greater force than he had. The painfully loud and angry curses of Epps load the air. Patsey by now is terribly lacerated, literally flayed. The lash wet with blood which flowed down her sides and dropped upon the ground. At length Patsey ceases struggling. Her head sinks listlessly on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her screams and supplications gradually decrease and die away into a low moan. It would seem that she was dying. Solomon, screaming at Epps:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thou devil! Sooner or later, somewhere in the course of eternal justice thou shalt answer for this sin! Though Epps fronts rage, there should be underlying anguish for what he has done to his beloved Pats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sin! There is no sin! A man does how he pleases with his property. At the moment, Platt, I am of great pleasure. You be goddamn careful I don't come to wantin' to lightenin' my mood no further. By contrast to this horror, the field of cotton smiles in the warm sunlight. The birds chirp merrily amidst the foliage of the tress. Peace and happiness seems to reign everywhere. Everywhere else. Epps leaves Patsey to herself. He says not a word to the Mistress as he passes. The Mistress herself heads back into the house. Solomon unties Patsey, lifts her and takes her to the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patsey is laid on some boards where she remains for a long time with eyes closed and groaning in agony. Phebe applies melted tallow to her wounds, and all try to assist and console her. In time Patsey opens her eyes. She looks to Solomon. She does not say a word. She just looks at him...and then her eyes close again.

dialogues.speaker: -APRIL, 1852-
dialogues.text: Solomon and Bass are working together alone on the extension. From the amount of work that's been done on it, it should be obvious that days have now passed. Solomon makes a cautious approach to Bass. As casually as he can he inquires:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Bass, I want to ask you what part of the country you came from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No part of this land. I was born in Canada. Now guess where that is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know where Canada is. I have been there myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montreal and Kingston and Queenston and a great many places. And I have been in York state, too. Buffalo and Rochester and Albany, and can tell you the names of the villages on the Erie canal and the Champlain canal. Bass gives Solomon a long and curious stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well traveled for a slave. How came you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Bass, if justice had been done I never would have been here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's this? Tell me all about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am afraid to tell you, though I don't believe you would tell Master Epps if I should.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every word you speak is a profound secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon holds a moment. Hasn't he heard the same promise before? Prior to Solomon stating his case, WE FADE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hours have passed. Bass reflects on the story that Epps has told in the intervening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many years all told?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just nearly...just passed eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your story is...it is amazing, and in no good way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe, sir, in justice as you have said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That slavery is an evil that should befall none?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you truly do, I would ask...I would beg that you write my friends in the north, acquainting them with my situation and beseeching them to forward free papers, or take such steps as they might consider proper to secure my release. Bass looks at Solomon, holding his gaze for more than a prolonged beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daughter Margaret is possibly now 19 and my son Alonzo, 16. I miss them so. It would be an unspeakable happiness to clasp my wife and my family again. Bass hands Solomon an end of a long plank of wood and looks over his shoulder, as if to camouflage the conversation by work. They both lift it toward the floorboards. Finally Bass speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have always forgone relationships and family. I did once have a sweetheart who I loved deeply. Bass points to a measuring tool, which Solomon immediately hands over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that was a long, long time ago. I've been traveling this country for the best part of twenty years. My freedom is everything. The fact that I can walk out of here tomorrow gives me most pleasure. I see the aching in your eyes, the pain of not being attached to your loved ones. My life doesn't mean much to anyone, but it seems your life means a lot to a lot of people. What you have just said to me scares me, and I must say, sir, I am afraid. Not just for you, but for me. They continue working, fixing the floorboards in unison. Solomon, slightly confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will write your letter sir, for if I could bring freedom to you, it will be more than a pleasure. It will be a duty. Now, would you be so kind as to pass me those nails, sir. We pull back to reveal the two men dwarfed by the unfinished structure. They continue to work, as if the conversation had never occurred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon walks a path he has walked a thousand times or more on his way back from Bartholomew's - sack familiarly slung over his right shoulder. Drearily he walks. His eyes acknowledge something we yet cannot see to his left. Almost simultaneously, his eyes retract back to the path

dialogues.speaker: A165 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: towards Epps'. As he passes out of shot, the evidence of what he was looking at is revealed. FEET hang at the top right hand corner of the frame. A woman, who has been lynched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To a now virtually complete, half-painted white gazebo. Slaves continue to work on it. As they do so, Bass peels away from the structure to have an overview. He beckons Solomon toward him, out of earshot from the slaves who are continuing to work on the gazebo. As Solomon approaches, Bass shouts-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And bring those markers! Solomon gathers a clutch of markers in his hands and approaches Bass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No letter yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are certain? Bass takes a marker from Solomon and slides it into the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have inquired thoroughly. More than is safe for either of us. Bass takes another and pokes it into the ground, improvising a pathway towards the gazebo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon...I have a job or two on hand which will be completed shortly... The work here has grown sparse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bass doesn't need to spell things out for Solomon. Solomon's understanding of the finality of the situation should be very clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must know, wherever I am I will press your cause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five months. On top of these years. No cause remains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there is any chance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bass...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will continue to write your

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home knowing you have tried. The weight of defeat should hang very heavily with both men. Nothing more to do, nothing more to say BASS TAKES

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON'S HAND, GRIPS IT FIRMLY, BUT LOW AND
dialogues.text: SURREPTITIOUSLY knowing full well he cannot be seen making contact with a slave. But in the strength of their collective grip, in the emotion in which they hold each other's eyes, we should be able to easily see how greatly Bass wanted to be able to help Solomon. Equally, we can see the depth of regard Solomon has for Bass. The moment is made all the more powerful by the fact neither man can openly speak his regret or thanks. A moment longer, and then Bass releases his grip and makes his way marching toward the gazebo, pointing instructions. Solomon is left, markers in hand, alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon sits on a secluded part of the road, fiddle in hand. He stares across the expanse. His eyes fixed on something that is a million miles away. Slowly Solomon tunes his fiddle, turning the tuning peg tighter and tighter. As the strings are taut, the sound is almost unbearable as Solomon tightens bit by bit, as if bones are being cracked one by one. Just beyond the breaking point of sound, there is a snap. He then repeats the action. Solomon holds the neck of the violin. Sliding his thumb and forefinger down the neck, he methodically cracks it at the base. He carefully snaps the neck and removes it from the body, then snaps it in two, placing it on the ground. He then starts on the body. Heaving it on the ground, it falls apart. Methodically he breaks the violin into small bits - silencing the instrument with a hushed display of violence, rather than aggressive. Seems almost to be, in an odd way, respectful.

dialogues.speaker: -FEBRUARY, 1853-
dialogues.text: The Slaves are sewing the heavily plowed field, making their way in the trying soil. Solomon, too focused to note the arrival of two men by carriage: Parker and the SHERIFF. While the Sheriff makes his way to the field, Parker remains with the carriage. The Sheriff calls:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Platt...? Where is the boy called Platt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Sir... The Sheriff crosses to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name is Platt, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Pointing off to the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know that man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon looks toward the carriage. He has to shield his eyes from the sun. Recognition is slow coming to him. But when it does, it hits him as a rush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Parker...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon starts for Parker, but he is pulled back by the Sheriff who is keen to determine Solomon's true identity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Parker? As he does, Epps makes his way over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man received a letter compiling many accusations. You look me in the eye and on your life answer me truthfully: have you any other name than Platt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon Northup is my name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you a family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's official business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My nigger, my business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your business waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me of your family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a wife and two children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were your children's names?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret and Alonzo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your wife's name before her marriage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Hampton. I am who I say. Solomon pushes past the sheriff. As Solomon moves toward Parker, his pace quickens with each step until his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: personal velocity has him nearly at a dead run. The two old friends make contact with each other, wrap each other in a long and emotional embrace. It if finally broken by Epps, who has moved over with the Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah... You will unhand 'em. Platt is my nigger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is Solomon Northup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He belongs to no man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say! You come here, unfamiliar to me, and make claims.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not claims. I have no doubts. This is Solomon Northup, a resident of Saratoga Springs, NY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To hell with that! My nigger, and I'll fight you for 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As is your right. As it will be my pleasure to bankrupt you in the courts. Your decision. By this time, the slaves in the plantation have overcome their fear of penalty, and left their work and gathered in the yard as witnesses. They stand behind the cabin, out of sight of Epps. Mistress Epps also bears witness, standing on the veranda next to her house slave. Her face is of a strange mixed emotion. Epps looks to Solomon. Solomon icily, stoically holds his ground. He makes it quite clear in his countenance that nobody owns him. Sheriff, hand on his gun, is there to back Solomon up. Epps, with no other recourse than to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think this is the last you'll see of me, boy? It ain't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever paper you hold about his freedom, it don't mean naught. He is my nigger - and I will have my day in court, sir. As God as my witness, I will have my day in court. Take 'em! Epps calls to Bob-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saddle my horse! And bring her up here. Epps walks back into the plantation. The trio starts for the carriage. Solomon is pulled back by the call of Patsey's voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Platt... Disregarding Parker, Solomon crosses over to Patsey. Under the circumstances, neither really knows how to engage. Finally, suddenly, Patsey throws her arms around Solomon and they embrace. Epps, now mounted on his horse, witness the encounter. Kicking the stirrups hard into the sides of the horse, he rides off furiously. Calling from the carriage, mindful of Epps:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon...if we know what's wise, we should depart. A moment longer Solomon and Patsey hold each other. They separate, Solomon heading back to the carriage. He and Parker alight. The Sheriff chides the horses and they

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: start up. As they move on, Patsey sinks down to the ground, where she remains in a weary and half-reclining state, the other slaves around her. WE STAY WITH Solomon as he travels further and further from the slaves - who are diminished by distance. Solomon waves a hand to them, but the carriage rounds a bend and a thicket of trees hides them from his eyes forever more.

dialogues.speaker: -MARCH, 1853-
dialogues.text: We now see Solomon in front of a door. A door we have seen before at the very beginning of our story. Solomon, aged significantly since then, stands nervously, swallowing, and adjusting his attire. He breaths in and holds his breath. He blows out and closes his eyes. A tear falls from his cheek, but this is not the way he wants his family to see him. He gathers himself, and looks to his right. There stands Mr. Parker. He places his hand on Solomon's shoulder. He says gently-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you ready? Solomon swallows and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DOOR TO THE ROOM OPENS. Mr. Parker enters, Solomon behind. We first see Anne, in her finest attire; the Northup children: Alonzo, who is now seventeen and Margaret who is now twenty - SHE CARRIES WITH HER A BUNDLE. Also present is MARGARET'S HUSBAND. The family waits patiently, dutifully...but anxiously. Anne rises to greet him, but holds back. All around, the body language of the family is stiff and awkward. They are, after all - after twelve years - little more than familiar strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize for my appearance. I have had a difficult time of things these past many years. Solomon looks among his family; trying to recall them as much as they look to see familiarity within him. To his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alonzo... Margaret, yes? You do not recognize me, do you? Do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you...do you even remember the last time we saw each other? I put you on a carriage with your mother... Margaret, tearing, hugs her father. Solomon almost breaks, but he keeps himself together. Looking to the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is my husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Husband?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is very good to meet you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have much acquainting to do. Margaret rises, she presents her bundle to her father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is your grandson. Solomon Northup Staunton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Solomon... The fact his grandson carries his name, is overwhelming. Solomon breaks down. Emotionally, physically... But ANNE IS THERE TO CATCH HIM. As she holds him, Solomon says to Anne with all his heart:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is nothing to forgive. The pair, joined now by the whole family, hold on to each other for life...and one would think for all the rest of their lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upon gaining his freedom, Solomon Northup located and attempted to seek legal justice against the men who kidnapped him. The case was tried in Washington, DC where blacks were prohibited by law from testifying

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: against whites. The charges against the kidnappers were eventually dismissed. Northup spent the rest of his life working as an abolitionist, and with the Underground Railroad. Solomon Northup most likely died between 1863 and 1875. The exact date, place, and circumstances of his death remain unknown.
